description:
Iced.mocha.period.

Be patient and you will be rewarded with this chocolatey goodness. This isn't Starbucks, so if you're on the run and need it in 30 seconds you've come to the wrong place. Come, stay awhile, take a breather and enjoy.
author: Rachel L.

description:
Isn't Mercury like the Roman god of speed? Yeah, the guy with the tin porkpie hat with the little wings glued on it. Anyhow, there is some point of irony I was trying to make about speed not being an atttibute of the customers who park themselves in here as they are generally individuals focused on their laptop screens, not making human contact, and barely making any movement (photo: http://bit.ly/2CfH1xR). Speed? It was more like a still life that was slightly breathing. The barista, however, was fleet of finger in her successful effort in making a solid $4 Cafe au Lait (photo: http://bit.ly/2NgAkQg). Since I didn't want to interrupt the still life inside, I took advantage of their parklet which bore only the slightest hint of auto fumes from the constant traffic on Octavia. Hell, I liked it there.

COFFEE - 4 stars...very smooth and rich
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...probably not zombie enough for indoor seating but I'm good in the parklet
SERVICE - 4 stars...the barista was kind and capable of human contact
TOTAL - 4 stars...just the right corner spot for a coffee break

RELATED - Looking for dining options in Hayes Valley? Here's a collection of places I've tried and reviewed: http://bit.ly/2L9VU3W
author: Ed U.

description:
I went for the portabello mushroom sandwich (and cappuccino). Listen, I can eat my share of meat but I figured I would give this non-deli and vegan option on their menu a try (after all, I'm in SF). Absolutely excellent decision. The red peppers were so creamy and delicious, and the whole wheat bread was thick, soft and oh-so-good. I found out the owner gets his bread from Acme nearby almost daily! Finished it off with a neat cappuccino which was a punch of bittersweet​ coffee and had a solid espresso in it to wake me up to do some work. 

Overall, a solid cafe with low noise and an excellent spot to grab lunch, a coffee, and just chill.
author: Emily C.

description:
Not to much to say about this cute little coffee shop on a corner of San Francisco's Octavia St. 
We walked in, my friend ordered her coffee and within 5 minutes she received it. There's a handful of tables, yet most of them were taken by hipsters on their MacBook Pros. There's a second level with a couple tables but again, those were taken. 

If you're looking for a cute local spot, so that you can drink coffee and be on your computer with low noise- then this is the neighborhood coffee shop for you.
author: Lene N.

description: Overall pretty meh. It's not bad, but not good enough either. I ordered iced tea and avocado toast (basic, I know), the iced tea is okay but the avocado toast is really bland. They could improve by adding a thin layer of spread. It's just sourdough toast topped with avocado. A little onion and olive oil. I tried to sprinkle lemon juice on it from the lemon wedge that came with it, no effect. I could have done better if I were to make it at home. It just feels like not much thought is given to it. Plus the AC is not strong enough for a warm day. I think 3 stars does it justice.
author: Jessie L.

description: Loved among digital nomads, I am one of them. I ordered a cup of coffee, $3.5. There's a handful of tables, yet most of them taken by hipsters on their Mac Book pros, after lunch time is too late for getting a seat. Why does this cafe attract them, one of the reasons is the feature of the area. Hays Valley is a really cool spot in San Francisco, I like walking this area in holidays. Mercury Cafe is such a remarkable spot for freelancers/remote workers. Check it out!
author: Shun Y.

description: $15 for two small coffee and a slice of pie? And the pie tasted three day old. Over priced and low quality food. I tried sooo hard to love this place since it's a block away from my house. But the grumpy old guy who works there needs Jesus.
author: Eric S.

description:
Major points for having free wifi and relatively inexpensive food and drink. Other than that this was a no-frills cafe that I don't think I'll be back to visit regularly. 

I ordered a chai latte. I liked that it was different (much spicier) than your average coffee shop chai.  

I forgot being Martin Luther King Day that the library would be closed, which is where I had planned to get a little work done. I tried to hit up another coffee shop and they too were closed. I almost gave up and was on my way home when I found this place on Yelp. I appreciate that Mercury was open but it was a pretty lackluster experience. Staff was friendly and it's entirely possible they weren't expecting as much business as they received this day (all the tables were full) however they were incredibly slow. They have lots of seating but it wasn't super inviting, felt a little awkward and cramped. They do offer food, not sure I'd try it after watching them make sandwiches without gloves (maybe that isn't a health violation in San Francisco). I just can't imagine they were diligent about washing their hands after touching the register, collecting dirty dishes and making food. 

Maybe it was an off day and I should give them another shot but I'll be sure to check out some other places in the mean time.
author: Tarah P.

description: What a treat! Of course all their coffee is delicious and on point but you have to try their in house strawberry scones!!!! I was luckily to stroll in around 7:45am and snagged a fresh out of the oven batch. So good! You can't beat a good coffee, scrumptious pastry and excellent customer service!
author: Sahar N.

description:
Walked in here on a rainy Friday afternoon. Once I saw the vegan chili on the menu, I had to have it!

Am I vegan? No. Do I love chili? Yes. I also got the Mocha as an accompaniment. 

I've got a bad case of the flu and this chili hit the spot man. Little spicy, thick, creamy. Great consistency. I loved it.

The mocha also rocked. I added a little brown sugar for some added sweetness. It was the perfect temperature and had a fantastic full-bodied flavor. 

If the food is this good when I have a flu I can't wait to try it when I don't!
author: Nicole W.

description: I have never been to a place with less sense of urgency than this one, there was no line so why 25 min for two sandwiches, in top of that apparently no mayo/mustard seems like too big of an issue.
author: Raul R.

description: I recently moved to the neighborhood and I am very excited about this cafe. I've been working in Hayes valley for a while but never been here. I have to say, AMAZING FRESH FOOD.  I ordered a roasted red pepper sandwich and it was so flavorful and fresh. I could taste all the veggies and the hummus was excellent. I got the combo with the awesome veggie chili . The chili was also really good with a hint of spice.  I am excited to go back.  The ambiance is nice. I sat outside in the sun and read a book.  The service is also very good. I will be back. This is a really good spot for a decent lunch.
author: Juanita H.

description:
This is a fantastic spot to get work done all day long! Free wifi, outlets, affordable food & drink, and music that drowns out other conversations but doesn't hurt your eardrums. There's also 3-hour parking a block away on Laguna if you're silly and drive in SF like I do. 

In addition to their usual coffee/espresso menu, there's freshly squeezed OJ, breakfast (bagels, toast, STRAWBERRY SCONES), lunch (soups, sandwiches), and alcohol (beer/wine). Most drinks fall under $5 and food really ranges. The avocado toast looks HUGE and all the sandwiches are freshly prepared behind the counter. It's kind of cool that sandwiches can be made into salads, why doesn't every place do this? 

I enjoyed my scone & soy latte, I probably would've gotten more work done if I wasn't so distracted by typical internet things. I really liked the bright open windows, but the breeze was a little much so I had to keep my jacket on. My favorite thing about this cafe (just kidding, there's two things!) is the welcoming feel of it. I've been to way too many hipster-ish cafes where I feel super out of place, but the crowd here is all over the place from older gentlemen writing in notebooks, to construction workers grabbing a quick lunch, to the typical 20 to 30-something typing away on their macbooks. 

They also serve Allagash on tap. That's probably what won me over the moment I walked in. If only it was anything but their Hoppy Table Beer!
author: Christine L.

description: Yummy vegan sandwiches and pastries! Bring your book and enjoy the fresh air at the outdoor sitting area.
author: Sevda G.

description: Off of Octavia and Gough this place is a mix of old school San Francisco and hipster parking. The food is ok, the coffee good and the ambience sunny. Don't expect super fast service - it's one person doing everything, so be kind!
author: Diana R.

description: The dirty chai latte was different than any other I have had in the past. The spices tasted so fresh, not packaged and powdered like most places do it. The ambiance of any coffee shop is very important to me and I look for places I can read and study comfortably. This place passed! The staff was friendly, location convenient, and who doesn't love that big wooden door?!
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
I've tried quite a few places now for laptop cafes - and I gotta say, this is so far my favorite.
Key requirements for a good place for me to work:
- Good coffee. It's an absolute must.
- Healthy food. I'm not here to treat myself..
- Nice atmosphere
- Decent wifi
- Electricity
- Ergonomic seating

This place covers it all, and then some. Food is not only healthy, but it's really tasty too. Clear flavors, good produce, great vegetarian options.
Atmosphere is light and inviting, staff is friendly and they make amazing coffee.

Outdoor seating is a great bonus, a chance to get some sun while working; yes please! (There are seats facing the sun, so you can still read your screen.)

Last time it rained it did get crowded, which kinda sucks for me, but I don't care - they deserve it all. I'm such a fan I just wanna shout it out the internet.
You'll find me here most weekends.
author: Mattis E.

description:
The space is cool (pun not intended.... Mercury and space. Haha) I was looking forward to checking out Mercury Cafe because it looked beautiful and airy with a high ceiling and lots of natural light. However, besides the lighting and the neat rustic door, I encountered a series of unfortunate events:

- There's a frickin PIGEON that nests in one of the lamps. I very genuinely detest pigeons aka flying rats, and this one was flapping its wings all over right on top of the tables! As if that weren't bad enough, it brushed off all the dust, feathers, and various disgusting things that accumulate in lamps, and you could actually see a shower of debris in the middle of the cafe. A dead bug and a dead spider landed on my laptop -___-;; At least I hadn't gotten my food or coffee yet.

- I wanted a bagel with hummus and they ran out, so I got tomato instead. I had expected some type of spread, but it was literally just a bagel with 3 slices of tomatoes and a small sprinkle of pepper. What a waste of the extra $2... I could have gotten an entire local organic gluten-free tomato from the farmer's market. (I believe it was $2.25 for the bagel + $2 for the tomato) At least the pigeon wasn't moving around as I was eating my overpriced tomato bagel.

- There were quite a number of flies; I'm not sure if there's a garbage dump nearby or something. A fly kept landing on my leg as I was eating my overpriced bagel, and I couldn't get it to go away--I must have looked like I had restless legs syndrome. 

That's my rant of exasperating issues; everything else was rather standard for an SF cafe--friendly hipster-ish barista and decent coffee (except I can't say I was too excited over the $0.25 extra charge for iced drinks). Mercury Cafe has a nice neighborhood cafe vibe, but the pigeon, the flies, and the tomato bagel disappointments were too out of this world for me.
author: Edna C.

description: Love the windows/natural lighting and the space. It's low key, and I feel comfortable working here. Their bathroom is large enough to fit a wheelchair.
author: Nanemone T.

description:
It's not the best coffee nor the best food you can get SF, but if you're looking for a good cafe to get some work done, this is your spot.

Plenty of tables, plenty of outlets, and Wi-Fi speed wasn't too shabby for a cafe. Plus there's big windows, so all the natural light makes you less likely to feel stir crazy if you're in here for a long period of time typing away on your laptop. 

P.S. I was actually worried about coming here after I read Edna C.'s review about pigeons nesting in one of the lamps inside (because fun fact: I'm terrified of birds). Happy to say that there were no pigeons when I went on a Sunday afternoon.
author: Sara L.

description:
The service here was terrible and slow. And the mocha I got was watery which is fine, it happens, but not for 5$. Their saving grace from 1-star was the friendly chef I struck up a convo with while waiting for the bathroom. 

Basically the cashier would get a drink order, have a convo, and make that drink then get the next and so on. I don't even know what the other two staffers were doing. True, this is a cafe, not Starbucks but we were second in line and both had time to use the bathroom before ordering. 

Also some of the staff did not look hygienic. I really don't care about this and hesitate to mention it but it was to the level that I feel I should say something... 

PROS: kitchen guy, big windows for natural light 
CONS: slowwwwww, poor drinks, troublesome staff
author: Olivia F.

description:
Fairly simple coffee cafe menu, they offer espresso drinks, salads, sandwiches and bagels. They're located at the corner of Octavia St so it shouldn't be hard to miss.

Inside is pretty small, looks like a 300sq ft sit in/prep area. There's a good amount of seatings, but when I went on a rainy Saturday late afternoon, they were packed! I ordered for a roast beef sandwich and it came with a small side salad with vinagarette. The sandwich was basic and the salad was just tossed in. Wish it could be dressed up with some twist. Customer service was good, would come back if I'm in the area.
author: Angela L.

description:
Had a really racist experience here this am. I work nearby and frequently come here for coffee/breakfast. Service is generally slow but it's never bothered me before. Today I was waiting for my breakfast sandwich and I inquired, after a long 15 minute wait, if it was ready. A customer joked with the barista that this wasn't the dollar menu and the barista explained (in a snooty way) that their food is freshly made. I'm a person of color and was really taken aback by their offensive tone. Mr. Barista and racist
Customer , you know nothing about me to assume that I frequent the dollar menu. Maybe this cafe is very white for a reason. I won't go here again and will be sure to tell my friends in the neighborhood about my experience.
author: Ana C.

description: Mercury Cafe provides the coffee for my soul, when it gets thirsty! I adore their single-origin coffee selections...today I had the one from Kenya--spectacular! Also, you cannot pass up their scones. The strawberry scone is always a treat and it's organic ;-). The only sad thing is that I now live far away, but I make it a mission to stop by when I'm in Hayes Valley.
author: Jeanette Jane G.

description: Great spot to grab coffee and get some work done. Lots of natural light and plenty of outlets! There are a lot of fancy hipster coffee spots in Hayes Valley, so it's nice to have a charming, laid-back neighborhood spot. While the food isn't out of the world, the prices are reasonable, the staff is friendly and the coffee is good!
author: Rachel L.

description:
The ideal working space for those us who need to get out of the house to be productive! I was in the neighborhood looking for a coffee shop to get some work done and this cafe immediately caught my eye. On a warm Saturday afternoon, the windows were open and the whole space was bright and open. 

The coffee was solid and the food looked pretty affordable/healthy with some vegan/vegetarian options. 

I would have to dock a star here just because I felt the wifi was pretty slow, but that may just have been the place was packed and too many people were using it. Tons of outlets and the high ceiling lets in tons of natural light and everyone else looks so focused on their work that it makes you feel a bit more productive too :) It looks like people stay here for a long time so I'd suggest coming slightly earlier in the day to grab a table!
author: Jingxi Z.

description:
The very polite cashier gave a great recommendation when I was choosing between a few sandwiches. The caprese sandwich he suggested and made was delicious (great bread, tasty mozzarella, and flavorful tomatoes), really filling (he definitely didn't skimp when he was slicing the mozzarella and tomatoes), and the price was right considering the sandwich was large and came with a mixed green side salad with a mustardy balsamic dressing. My boyfriend said his beef sandwich was very tasty as well. Food came out relatively quickly though we were the only people ordering at the time so I can't speak to what it's like when it's busier. The space was open, attractive, and seemed like a nice place to get some work done as there were a lot of people quietly doing just that. 
I'll definitely be back!
author: Anna D.

description:
Ordered a $3.75 iced tea, tipped and sat down to do a little work. Was asked to order more or leave after 55 minutes. I would understand if the place packed, but it was maybe half full at 4 pm. 

Won't be coming back.
author: David P.

description:
Home of the $12 deli sandwich. Comes w a small bit of lettuce salad w some croutons.  Repeat-$12 deli sandwich. 

There's no sign on the outside that I could see. Maybe this is to keep people from writing on Yelp about their super-high prices. 

The sandwich was good but it's 50% higher price of similar establishments/sandwiches.
author: Louis L.

description: This spot gets a lot of light, has comfortable chairs and tables big enough to spread work out on, and very friendly staff.
author: Gia F.

description:
I recently went to this cute lil coffee place to see an old freind but left slightly disappointed. It costed 13.50 for black tea and two bagels with cream cheese and tomato! 
My brother ordered a iced coffee and for 3.75 came a fair portioned size of some bottom of the barrel coffee ! 
While the place is cute and workers are quite nice I remain disappointed.
author: Aidan B.

description: I knew I'd been avoiding this place for a while but I couldn't remember why.  Then last week I went in and it all came back to me.  They are always busy which is understandable.  The barista is working hard.  I place my order, latte and a bagel with cream cheese and tomato.  On my way to the bathroom, I get yelled at "This is a hot pan!" by a young person with green hair carrying out fresh scones.  Fine, people get stressed.  I'm in the bathroom for two minutes and I keep hearing the barista shouting out my latte is ready.  She looks annoyed when I arrive to pick it up.  I then sit and wait and wait and wait for the bagel.  The green hair person returns to the front, looks at the food orders lining up, and goes into the back.  Maybe they prepare the food there?  At least someone knows they're waiting.  After 10 minutes with no food coming out to anyone, I return to the counter and am told that "She's working on the avocado toast right now."  Sure enough, the barista is now prepping food.  Okay, must be someone else's order.  I want to ask for a refund and get back to work but I'm trying not to be a bitch, so I wait.  Avocado toast gets delivered.  Counter guy is now in the back.  Barista is making food while greenie stands next to her, crying, about who knows what.  I go up to cancel but then see my bagel is cut, tomato is sliced, just needs cream cheese and assembly.  The barista turns to me and I let her know "I'm waiting for the bagel."  She says, "I'm working on it."  As I return to my seat, I hear her say "As you can see!"  WTF?  I wait 20 MINUTES for a bagel, am kind and patient, and I'm met with attitude and no apology.  The latte wasn't even for me and so when I delver it, it's lukewarm at best.  Never coming back.
author: Sandra H.

description: I must say the staff are a confused bunch. I needed a quick to-go bagel and I had to wait a whole 15 minutes. No one's actively working on my bagel. And honestly the hummus in the bagel was mediocre and messy and the bagel costs 4.50. Coffee wasn't great either.
author: Edward Huang R.

description:
Rich chocolate mocha with vegan chocolate! I've never heard of Rechiutti chocolate till now! They also do 24 hr cold brews so you know it's legit. Why are their French presses only offered during the morning? 

Very spacious and filled with ppl doing work! Perf study spot.
author: Diane H.

description: I LOVE this place. I go all the time, and it's kind of out of the way for me. I really like the atmosphere of this cafe, it just super chill. They have great coffee and really good food. I always get an americano with the portabello mushroom sandwich as a salad. They have huge windows, and when it's really nice out they open them and it just pure bliss. Definitely check this place out.
author: Nikki H.

description: Cute little cafe! I spent a few hours here on a weekday morning working. The mocha was good and the staff was great. They have free wifi and plenty of outlets!
author: Nirati G.

description: This is one damn good corner somewhere in heart of San Francisco! They serving their type of food that sure appreciate any people that visits here as well as serving fresh hot brew coffeeee! Come and agree with me!
author: Dominic A.

description:
I just happened to come across Mercury Cafe as I was roaming through Hayes and I'm glad I did! The dining atmosphere was very bright, open and welcoming. 

The two gentleman working the front counter were really friendly and the service was faster than I expected (one of them was wearing a Cure shirt so extra points for that). I ordered a Cold Brew & a Multigrain Bagel and both were perfect. 

I noticed a lot of younger professionals eating/working and the music they played was better than most cafes I've been to. People definitely seemed to enjoy the space. 

Overall, I had a great first experience here and will definitely come back.
author: Connor M.

description: favorite neighborhood spot for chillin + doing work. saw some people complaining about the sandwich cost- 12-13$ is standard in Hayes valley and the sammies here are pretty stacked. great wifi, great coffee, nice people.
author: Andrew C.

description:
Came here on a Sunday afternoon to get some work done and it was great.

Wi-Fi was fast, outlets were plentiful and there was also lots of tables. The cafe is designed with lots of natural lighting seeping in through its large windows so I suspect on a very sunny day this place can get quite hot. 

I had their cold brew which was nothing to rave about other than it was a solid cup of coffee.
Their scone on the other hand was absolutely delicious. Crispy crust and a soft inside, the hit of sugar you get from the crust is delectable.
author: Sean S.

description: No flavored iced coffee! But it's nice for just sandwiches and hot coffee very calming vibes. Seen plenty of people with laptops and on their phone lol
author: Yessica M.

description:
So I'm reading this book right now where it feels like scones are mentioned maybe every 3 pages. Characters are near constantly buttering scones and gorging themselves on the flaky crumbly goodness and I can't take it anymore. I need a scone rightthisfuckingsecond.

Yelp tells me that Mercury makes a great scone. There are tons of reviews with people raving about these amaa@@aa@zing scones, but I'm thinking they're maybe a little nuts, because how good can a scone actually be? If there was an elementary school play put on about baked goods, the scone's only lines would be "Oh no, I simply couldn't! I am but a humble scone!" 

I go anyways, the craving can't be denied.

They pull out a fresh batch right when I arrive, I sit down with my scone and a chai, and that's it for me. I'm done. I was doing that combination of scarfing because it's so good and eating obscenely slow in order to savor it. It's warm, it's perfect, with fresh bits of strawberry hiding in its pockets. I am losing it over how good this thing tastes. The crust is crumbly and perfectly sweet, the insides are just ohhhhhh, words fail me. This is the scone to end all scones.

The sweet and dirty iced chai also comes highly recommended. It has a slight spiced kick to it, which is perfect. It's actually similar to how chai is supposed to taste, with none of that saccharine nonsense you see in most coffee shops. I polished these two guys off in 10 minutes flat, and then grabbed a second scone to go. Already looking forward to popping it in the oven and having it for afternoon tea in a few hours.

To summarize: get the scone, get the chai, ignore me in the corner tripping out over how much I fucking love my scone.
author: Dede G.

description: Great place to work. Very quiet with great WiFi and lots of plugs. The bagels were great and the coffee was average. Will come again for work.
author: Ali Y.

description: Came here for some coffee and wifi, stayed for EPIC fresh lemonade and good music. Upon entry, the cute barista complimented the fact that my shoes and purse were holographic and matching. There are enough outlets that people can work all day and not fight over them, and enough of a delicious variety of food and drinks that I didn't have the urge to leave once in like four hours. Can't wait to come back.
author: Lauren Y.

description: The coffee is still great, and I saw the owner walk in with a huge bag of Acme bread. The sandwiches I've seen look really appealing. The staff has been really nice and bring you your items when ready. I can dig it.
author: Michelle M.

description:
This is the kind of space you sit down, grab a cup of coffee or tea, and post up & get shit done. 

It's located on a busy corner in terms of car traffic, but as far as people traffic, not too many folks are walking past this place, do it's peaceful, especially on a Saturday for the city.

I tried both an iced tea & an iced coffee, both were pretty great. The tea was lovely and not sweetened (which I prefer). 

The service was great. The barista was very friendly and the cafe was chill. I got a ton of work done, which is exactly what I wanted and the barista wasn't making me feel bad or anyone feel bad for just ordering a drink . 

I'd highly recommend this place for free-lance workers searching for a spot to work at!
author: Renee R.

description:
Ive only been here once and I thought it was so so....not the best cafe but still good. We got there at 10 and they had already run out of bagels and hot chocolate. So I ordered tea because lately I'm lactose in tolerant when it comes to milk and I also ordered one of their freshly baked scones which was bomb diggity! Nice and soft and warm!

The cafe itself is very spacious and has good seating. My boyfriend ordered a caprese sandwich which was $10 and good but way over priced! It wasnt the best I've tried but it was decent. He also ordered a latte and that wasnt too strong and had a great taste so I was pleased with that. 

My yogurt was straight up greek yogurt and tasted like sour cream with some granola and blue berries. But hey...at least I felt happy eating it ;)

Overall, this cafe was ok. Parking sucked of course cuz its SF and its on the corner so not too tough to find.
author: Alicia H.

description:
I have had great food and great experiences at this cafe for a thousand reasons.

The food is excellent. The environment is really open, inviting, and friendly, and, most importantly, the owners of this establishment are incredibly humble, friendly, and invested in their community. I can't recommend this place highly enough, and the primary reason is that when I go here I don't worry one bit about where my money is going. We need more local places like this in San Francisco.
author: Brad C.

description:
Today, after 4th of July, it's pretty empty and thus the wifi is fast. We came here for a light lunch after a 7-course barbecue last night with 2 heapings of desserts.


---- FOOD ----

Holiday sandwich: 3.5 stars
Turkey cranberry a little dry, sauce is unevenly spread. Stacked with turkey slices

Roasted Red Pepper Sandwich: 4 stars
Hummus arugula feta. A solid, fresh sandwich served with side salad, of which the dressing was a delicious vinaigrette with mustard seeds.


According to my partner, they make delicious lattes too.  Unfortunately, at some point in the afternoon the staff turned on more pumping-thumping music that made it more difficult to concentrate on reading, so we had to leave.  It's still a great location for me, and I'd come back with noise-cancelling headphones I guess?
author: Letitia L.

description:
OK seriously I have no idea why this place is rated 4 stars. The service was terrible. The staff are either all half asleep or too spaced out to notice. While the staff member was taking our order the other staff member was telling her some other information in front of us. So unprofessional.  I got the biscuit egg and tomato. It took ages and literally was the driest thing ever. I got a breakfast hot tea with it. That was brought without a spoon. When I asked for some milk the server came back with a giant carton of milk for me to pour. There was nowhere to put the teabag. My wife couldn't stop staring at a giant spider web with a spider eating a fly. At least someone was satisfied here. 
The food took an age and it was not even busy her. It also came without a knife. 

I won't be back. It is scruffy but not in an endearing way, in a run down way. The music is stoner gold. Literally tracks of people screeching. The staff are real bad and the food was one star. Oh dear.
author: Adam G.

description:
This is a fabulous neighborhood cafe, with great customer service and yummy food. I've come in here dozens of times and everyone is courteous, the plan is super clearn, the wifi is free and fast, and the Avocado sandwich is heaven.  

It's even got places for you to sit outside and read/talk.  The only downside is that it borders a very busy (read noisy) street. But just focus on your coffee & sandwich and you'll be good to go!
author: Cynthia B.

description: NOT a place for vegans. (Saying this up front bc a lot of the former reviews mention vegan pastries etc and that is why we came here.) HOWEVER, the cold brew was delicious and I got an everything bagel with avocado that hit the spot. Staff were super kind and friendly, and apologetic about not having more vegan offerings. They said it got expensive to make vegan pastries that just sat on the shelf.
author: Devon K.

description:
Love the roast beef sandwich here.  
Fresh ingredients.
Large portions.
Friendly service.
Great outdoor patio.
author: Linda N.

description:
This place is asleep
They forget your order 
Or bring it after everyone else has eatin 
Don't even bother unless you wanna surf the Internet
author: Robert S.

description: Can't very well give it a 1 when I've only had a pour-over coffee, can I? Seems nice enough, with cool art, though the coffee is undrinkable and the staff is a bit grumpy, to match the brooding goth music. I have a feeling it's just that kind of day around here.
author: Be F.

description:
Extremely nice people, excellent atmosphere and great sandwiches/coffee.
We wanted to go to Straw (next door to this place) but the people over there were extremely rude with over an hour wait time. Now we're actually very happy that they were rude so that we could discover this place...! Will definitely come here again, great for brunch/breakfast, hanging out with friends or studying/reading a book.
author: Babak G.

description: Not sure what's happened? The fresh squeezed juice was $6.00 and was literally about one cup. They were out of English muffins. Out of multiple other items on the menu (and it was only 10am) Mismatched glassware because we were told that the rest had gone missing?? Everyone seemed miserable and completely unapologetic for the lack of food, silverware or service. Meh! This charming sweet spot was a total hole :(
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Great staff; friendly and helpful. Good coffee beverages. Unimpressive food selection, so I didn't even bother staying and trying out anything they had to offer.
author: Felicia B.

description: Had a turkey sandwich with chipotle mayo. Very tasty, and large portion, so had the rest of it for lunch the next day (still good then).
author: June W.

description:
I really enjoyed lounging here while sipping on some caffeine and doing some productivity on Wi-Fi - especially along the open windows!  It was nice looking out while having a breath of fresh air.

Their macchiato is strong here and they surprisingly offer beer at a cafe shop!

It's a laid back, chill, corner cafe shop that doesn't draw attention.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
One of the best cold brew iced coffees I have tried in the Bay Area. If you order it "for here", they serve it in a big ol' pint glass. I asked for mine with soy milk, and the barista kindly obliged. They also have almond milk, but lately I've been more of a soy gal. 

It's weird how time changes us, isn't it?

Mercury offers free Wi-Fi, but I was too chicken to ask for the password. For someone who claims to be such an extrovert, I guess I'm actually pretty shy and nervous, especially when I think the barista fella is kind of cute (in that tall, gangly, mildly hipster sorta way). What can I say, I'm single and apparently ready to mingle *wink wink, nudge nudge* 

They were playing some good '80s records, which I really appreciated. This seems to be one of those laptop cafes, so if you want to chit-chat, you're probably better off doing it on their outdoor patio area. 

Would I return? Absolutely! It's a quaint, cozy spot just off Octavia Street, a hop, skip, and a jump from Civic Center or Van Ness. They also offer some vegan soups and possibly sandwich options. I had just eaten, so I didn't look too closely at the food menu, but even a bagel with avocado or hummus would pair nicely with your coffee du jour.
author: Brandi W.

description:
I stopped in here with Vanessa S while we were on our way to music trivia. Vegans and vegetarians will love this spot since they offer a bunch of different healthy options. We both ordered the white bean soup which actually looked more like chili. It was really tasty though so I'm not complaining at all.

The staff are super friendly as well. He offered us to go cups and even taped them closed so we wouldn't have to worry about extra spillage.

It's a pretty no frills place with decent prices. If I'm in the area again, I'd probably stop by. I saw lots of folks on their laptops here.
author: Amy J.

description: Great place to get a coffee and scone and just chill out / get some work done. Free wifi, lots of seats and good service.
author: Lauren C.

description:
I came here to grab a quick bite with Amy J. last night before trivia night at 1772 Market. This is a nice corner cafe. They have a nice option of sandwiches to choose from. 

The guy taking the order took awhile to find what I wanted on their iPad, but he was very nice. Amy and I both ordered the White Bean and Sausage Soup with a side salad. When we got it, we ended up getting the 3 Bean Chili. Oh well, it was still good.
author: Vanessa S.

description: This place is awesome! Good coffee and free wifi! I always pass this place on my way to getting on the freeway. Glad I Yelped it and decided to use as my office for the day! Big open windows with lots of natural light!
author: Rodney D.

description:
I like to come here to work a few times a week. Very relaxed environment free Wi-Fi is a plus and the main draw in addition to proximity. I appreciate their true independent cafe status, which signs all over are quick to point out. The staff is always friendly and pleasant. My main complaint is with the tea selection. I cannot comment on coffee as I am not a coffee drinker. It's probably decent... I don't think a cafe can survive in this town without decent coffee. I digress, the tea selection is bagged Stash brand teas. 

This is a general gripe for a lot of cafes from me so please don't feel singled out, dear Mercury Cafe. But why oh why do cafe's think that serving what amounts to be the Folger's coffee of the tea world is acceptable? As an avid tea drinker I implore you to find a better tea. In general it tastes like, well, nothing. Additionally, Stash Tea is not local. If you want to serve amazing tea from a local supplier, then there are options! Really good options! Delicious loose leaf options that won't make this tea lover cry on the inside when she is asked to shell out $2.50 for a mug of dark, hot water with a bag floating in it (I mean, let's be real that bag of dried flavorless plant matter cost you $0.10 at MOST and I wouldn't even care if it tasted good, but it doesn't... $2.50 is pretty steep. no pun intended. ha!). 

If you change this one thing about your cafe this tea lover would be a most devoted tea drinking customer. I would even stop moping about the fact that you charge $7 for a bowl of granola. I get it, I get it, it's organic and local. yada, yada, yada. In fact, I would even go as far as to end this review on a good note-- I like the music in here and in all of my visits I have never heard anything even remotely as terrible-sounding as whales dying. I mean, most of it I'm not going to go out of my way to listen to or buy BUT I appreciate hearing the musical meanderings of the staff while I work...and sip my flavorless tea as my heart weeps inside my chest. Ha. Sorry I couldn't resist. 

Anywho, this cafe is a great place to work and I will keep coming for that reason. Maybe I shouldn't tell you that... I mean, I'm taking a stand against bad tea. :P Ok, I think you get the point.
author: Meagan M.

description: Disgusting service!!!! The people who work here are rude, unprofessional, forgetful and slowwwwwwww!!! Note to management: hire better.  Note to customers: avoid unless you don't mind waiting 3 hours for rude service and a tuna sandwich.
author: Foodeater F.

description: Everyone in here is completely stoned. Which is fine, but it took 45 minutes and $38 for them to hand us the completely wrong order. We asked for an avocado sandwich on a garlic bagel, and a roast beef sandwich. They gave us 1 roast beef sandwich with avocado on a garlic bagel. They also asked us 3 times and we ordered to-go, but they still made our drinks and food for-here. We should have asked for our money back. In the time we were waiting for our order they also screwed up 3 other people's orders. The way this guy does business is ancient and inefficient and the staff he hires are just as awful as him. Overpriced too. We weren't in a rush before we got here but by the time we left we were running late. Will never come again, even if it's just for a simple coffee.
author: Katie L.

description: Great atmosphere but pricey. Double shot red eye was $7, normally its $4 in most places. Wifi a bit on the slow side but it works and is free.
author: Anon Y.

description:
Wait a half hour for a lukewarm wrong order. No thanks. 

 Yelp wants this to be longer actually added as a review dictate meaningless text.
author: M F.

description: Happily stumbled upon this cafe when looking for an afternoon work spot. Nice guys and good wifi, and I love the local vibe. I'll be back.
author: Matt H.

description:
It's a pretty decent spot -- big and spacious.  Very San Francisco -- sparse in its coffee additions: no artificial sweetners, or flavored syrups.  The coffee is pretty good though.

The sandwiches are a tad overpriced for what they are, and the barista (at the least the one I had) is a little derpy.  I live a block away on Haight, so this does in a pinch but I personally prefer Cafe La Vie 2 blocks down.
author: Steve A.

description: Fast wifi, chill neighborhood, good food menu (dear lawd the horseradish on the roast beef is spicy), intriguing dessert menu. Good for working.
author: B H.

description:
On a cold, brisk day, my girlfriend and I came in here to warm up and get off our feet for a while. She had coffee and I tea. For me, it wasn't so much the tea (which was fine - possibly Mightyleaf brand) as the environment that really won me over. The music and the people were both non-intrusive, so you could just hang out and relax. 

Also a nice touch, some veggie/vegan options that looked tasty.
author: Jon T.

description:
What a great little cafe! Roomy. Great light. Solid food/coffee choices. 

Ambiance: 5 stars. Never too crowded. Always a great music selection (they play new music every Tuesday). Positive vibes. Great, great natural light. 

Working from home score: 5 stars. Reliable internet (cafe internet as well as reliably xfinity connection). Plenty of outlets. 

Food: Solid 4 stars. They have great coffee. Simple and delicious sandwiches. They also have a few beers on tap-- for the more relaxed work/reading mood.  

I hesitated to write this review because it feels like my secret place. But it really does deserve 5 stars. Yay Mercury!
author: Carson S.

description: This place is freaking awesome, I come here almost every weekend! They have the friendliest staff and some chill music. Their food is a great treat, it's all organic and they bake all the scones and biscuits the same day. I would definitely recommend either the lentil or three bean chili and the kenya coffee. If you're reading this, you should just go it'll be great trust me.
author: Dalia X.

description:
We didn't mean to end up at Mercury. Ignorant tourists we were, following the trail of hype toward a big fat blue bottle. We bought some beans but they failed to grind them for us. They were somehow too cool of a coffee establishment to have a coffeeshop, annoying. Anyways, desperate and confused, we stumbled across what seemed to be a mirage. 

We were no longer on planet earth. We had finally made it to Mercury. The kind and charming inhabitant, Nick, welcomed us with otherworldly hospitality. The coffee was a delight and the accommodation was supreme. They sell kombucha! The sandwiches made my mouth water. This is a SF gem.
author: S S.

description:
Keeping this short:

+ Great Americano
+ Friendly baristas--in a barista way
+ WiFi 
+ Lots of tables to read, study, or just get shit done on your computer
+ Outdoor seating

- Kitchen in the back looks a little messy. Food still comes out lookin' delicious.
- Honestly, sandwiches are overpriced. I didn't have one, but also won't probably have one since they all start around $11.

All in all, I like this place!
author: Tik P.

description:
The laid-back SO-Cal vibe is what I get from Mercury Cafe.  You might as well be on another plant as the name suggests.  The space is quiet with people spaced out on lack of sleep and caffeine, starring endlessly into their computer screens or books.  The "barista" behind the counter also quietly waits for you to say hello as you gloss over the menu once or twice.  Service was fairly quick as the coffee shops in the surrounding area gather most of the attention.

All-in-all Mercury Cafe is a nice place to go and get away from it all. The coffee wasn't half bad but a bit watered down for my first time experience.  I'd go here if I had no other options.
author: Kevin J.

description: Mercury Cafe is great in so many ways.  It offers a simple and delicious menu, good coffee and an excellent environment.  The only downside is the portions are small, but that's to be expected from a cafe.
author: Kevin S.

description:
Fan of fast food but don't want to ingest the Frankenfoods of McDonalds or Burger King? Two words for you: the McMercury breakfast sandwich. A delicious poached egg, fresh tomatoes, and breakfast meats sandwiched between a fresh-baked biscuit and made to order. The only serve it for a few hours per day, and it's worth popping in for a quick bite before jetting off to work.

For those who enjoy working from coffee shops, this might be one of the best to do so in town. It's comfy, airy, and they have free wifi to boot. I'll have to make more of an effort to work remotely from Mercury more often!
author: Ruggy J.

description:
I'm a creature of habit when it comes to my lunch and one sandwich in the city that I cannot have enough of is caprese sandwich.  The basil is super fresh and tasty and the balsamic vinegar compliments it so nicely. I get so disappointed when they run out of the Dutch crunch roll. It's my favorite sandwich in the city. All the sandwiches come with a lightly dresses salad and for a good price of about $10. They take cards but prefer cash. They have wifi and a quiet space to work. There are plenty of tables and even an upstairs if you really want to focus and be secluded from the other customers. 

The outdoor patio on Octavia gets a lot of sun in the afternoon and they keep the area super clean.
author: Kelly C.

description:
This is my go-to place for working, meetings, or just hanging out!! Great food, great music and vibe, and awesome baristas who will chat with you and dance while making food if you're lucky. 

I'm hesitant to review this spot and let it be known that it's my favorite place in the city, because i don't want it to be overrun :)

They just added a parklet so more outside seating is always a plus.
author: I. L.

description:
When I first wrote my review I guess the owner was helping me. And I should also say that most of the staff are nice and attentive.

Since that review I guess they've hired a couple new people - or maybe they were already working there and I had never seen them working before. At any rate, some of these folks seem like they don't care a whole lot - stuff like service, cleaning tables, doing basic things like preparing your drink in the order it was received even if it's as simple as a mocha. I get it - you have to stir the chocolate in the espresso and it takes longer than serving a cup of tea. That's not a commentary on your job, I'm just not sure it takes 5 minutes to eventually get around to my mocha when there's no one else you were helping and when I walked in you were leaning against the counter listening to the really cool punk music.

But you can only be so frustrated with ordering a mocha, right? I mean it's just a mocha. Just kinda wish I could walk in there and order a coffee drink without wondering what kind of attitude I'll be greeted with that particular day, how you're going to talk to me, figuring out what chip you have on your shoulder and why. Although it does add to the excitement and practice of dealing with unhappy people. I used to work in a coffeehouse to make ends meet so I had probably dished out my fair share of attitude back then.
author: Emmett K.

description: A cafe with a good selection of food, plenty of seats, and a friendly atmosphere. The food is good too -- I had an avocado toast which was packed with avocado slices (duh!) and very delicious. I can see this place being a great afternoon hangout, getting some munchies and lingering over coffee with some friends.
author: Alice C.

description:
I gotta say that I was really excited to try this place after reading the positive reviews and sorely disappointed after eating here.

Price: at $8.75/sandwich you expect something pretty large in size or alternatively something pretty delicious.  This caprese sandwich I ordered met neither of these criteria.  Similarly, my co worker who ordered the turkey sandwich had the same blase feeling.

I guess if you were going to sit at the cafe and use their space to work/study the price to value ratio might be higher but for regular lunch folks I would say go elsewhere...

Also, they had a sign for organic pies for $28...I'm not a big pie eater but that seems unjustifiably expensive....
author: Betty C.

description: Good place! Good price. Good coffee. I found French press coffee which is more stronger than espresso. And you know it's biger than shot of espresso. Recommended coffee and place
author: Vadim R.

description: This place is great!  The scones are made fresh and absolutely delicious.  The code brew iced coffee is fantastic.  I also love the bright open windows and the sun comes through.  It's a great place to study, might be favorite spot now.  The sandwiches are huge too!  Only positives for this place.
author: Tammy N.

description: One of the few cafés in the city that serves up great food with high speed internet and a chill place to do work.
author: Jacob K.

description: Had a cup of coffee and a bagel both were great, there's outdoor seating as well as Wi-Fi.
author: Timothy K.

description:
Solid, free wifi. 12 tables with 2 upstairs, so plenty of seating. Younger crowd. They also serve soups, salads, and sandwiches.

Pretty solid place to come, get work done, and be seen typing into your macbook air.
author: Andy J.

description:
My favorite place in the city to chill out and get some work done. I love the atmosphere of this light filled cafe. Always a wide variety of music playing, and super friendly staff.

The food is great, especially all of their sandwiches on wheat bread.

The only complaint I have is that the coffee is very expensive and only mediocre.
author: Lawson F.

description:
They take Square! A hip coffee bar, though you'll usually find me here drinking tea. There's an ample pulse here, but it ain't too busy either.

Protip: they keep the door open, so if you sit along the east-facing windows, you'll get a draft. Keep your jacket around.
author: Christophe C.

description: Just ordered a regular drip coffee and met with a Recruiter at the cafe.  Coffee is just Okay. Too acidic for me. Seats are too closely to each other. I was afraid of being too loud while I was talking. Another funny thing was that the tables we sat was not even. My coffee kept falling out of the cup. Very embarrassing for me.
author: Carrie Z.

description:
Was walking through Hayes Valley this weekend and pulled up Yelp on my iPhone as I wanted to find some place where I could park my rear end for an hour, grab a coffee and sandwich, and (try to) look reasonably productive by checking emails. So Mercury Cafe fit the bill. 

I had an Americano, and while it was a bit watery, my hearty turkey sandwich on whole wheat with a smattering of cranberry sauce more than made up for it. Lots of tables with power outlets everywhere, and lots of young professionals studying, working, or conversing - exactly the kind of moderately busy coffeehouse scene I love when I need to get stuff done. The decor was rather rustic, but then again I'm looking for an honest-to-goodness coffeehouse, not an upscale bar.

Thank you, Yelpers, for this great find!
author: Vincent L.

description: Food was really good! It's nice to be able to pay for a smaller portion size if you aren't as hungry. Staff was incredibly friendly and helpful. Will definitely be again next time I'm in the area!
author: Julia C.

description: Great food and coffee, but the slowest service I've ever experienced...even when they aren't busy. Thirty minutes for a sandwich with no one ahead of me?
author: Kenton W.

description:
This is my favorite cafe in Hayes Valley. Good selection of vegetarian (and some vegan) food options, great drip coffee and kombucha when they have it, usually good music, and plenty of power sources and free internet. 

Only suggestion- please turn down the volume of the overhead music!! The last several times I've come in the music was blaring making it difficult to even have a conversation or concentrate while reading. One time had to leave cause it triggered a bad migraine.
author: E H.

description: I picked this cafe as a place to work for an afternoon. It has plenty of natural light and fresh air, there is complimentary wifi and no shortage of electrical outlets. It also wasn't very crowded on a weekday afternoon. The espresso was below average, pretty bitter and slow to be prepared. The orange cranberry scone I had was delicious. It was tender and buttery and a real treat for all of my hard work. The sandwiches other people ordered looked and smelled great, but seemed over priced.
author: Colleen M.

description: This is my go to spot for coffee meetings. I've now been here four times, but I must admit, I've never had anything to eat or drink.  For this it's great. The staff are stoned, so you can sit forever. And the location is perfect ( Coming from sunset? right off fell/oak street. Taking bart/muni? 2 blocks. Southbay person? Right off the 101) and there's always free street parking within a couple of blocks. Just watch out for street-cleaning Tuesdays from 12-2.
author: Alex M.

description:
5 stars! I sit with a coffee, savoring that charming experience of being in a corner cafe on a rainy day for perhaps one of the last times, as we continue to inch our planet closer to desertification by the day, and San Francisco's climate evermore resembles that of what I thought only belonged to Los Angeles. Insofar as that means our beaches may one day be as littered with bikini-clad young women as the beaches of our southern counterpart, I guess I ought to complain a little less. (You have to weigh the pros and cons, people). However, I still don't see SF City College beginning to resemble Orange Coast College in terms of talent level any time soon.
Unabashed misogyny aside (someone has to keep the old ways alive, folks, for the sake of future generations), this place has a good vibe, friendly folks, delicious fare, just the right amount of modern avant-garde vocal-cello-horn compositions piping through the speakers to make you feel just the right amount of erudite (I mean, this IS San Francisco, gotta keep up with the Murphy-Mulvey-Bishop-Joneses (...umm, like, they're polyamorous parents? Hell-OH-o! They were all on molly at the bottom of a cuddle puddle at a projection-mapping DJ set at Burning Man at 3:33am, muffled whispers, wandering hands and the rest was, as they say, history... or the future... or, like, the spontaneous unfolding manifestation of the present moment?) who have, I'm pretty sure, both Jeremiah Rain AND Karuna Sunshine enrolled in Farsi-speaking experimental jazz dulcimer elementary school).
Alright folks, quit reading this drivel, take your nose out of your goddamn cell phone, take out your earbuds, and go see what you find. Hell, it might even be another... PERSON! In a body, just like you! There you go...that's it...you can do it.
author: Brian B.

description:
Sorry, I don't understand what is good about this place. The only pluses I experienced were the sunny windows and a location near me. The people making and serving the food did not look like they had showered.  The bathroom smelled up one end of the seating area of urine. The music was bizarre, offensive "I wanna f-ing tear you apart"? and way too loud. My soup was forgettable and the tea was hot, but obviously old.  The staff was courteous but kind of dirty and gross, sorry. There it is. 
Won't be going there again. :(
author: Anne C.

description: The sandwich I got was so boring and bland. The mushrooms were stale. Nothing great about this place.
author: Hruthika C.

description:
Great cafe to get work done. The place is a no frill, local cafe with lots of space and large tables, perfect for working. They also have lots of magazines and comics, if you just want some distraction. 
I didn't try their food but they have great, refreshing ice tea. 
My only complaint is that they play the music pretty loud, so if you want to focus, bring a headphone.
author: Nancy Z.

description:
I love this cafe!!!  It's a nice little place in a corner, with a laid back ambiance.  The Eggs Mercury and their roasted potatoes -only served on weekends- are to die for!  Also, I'm a Latina and I like my coffee strong and flavorful; and boy, do they deliver!   Their coffee is great... Strong enough without being bitter.  The cappuccino's are awesome!

Their sandwiches are also very good.  I've had the turkey and ham, my husband the pastrami.  These are all tasty and they're pretty good in terms of size, you won't go hungry... Green salad is nice and fresh.

I honestly don't have anything bad to say... During a month-long stay in SF, I kept coming back because I loved the food so much.   People are nice too...
author: Yayra S.

description: Super hip place! Staff are very nice and friendly. Great spot for the Sunday morning coffee!
author: Kiana B.

description:
I got the breakfast special which includes potatoes and eggs on toast. Pretty delicious and certainly filling. You can get a single for $6 and a double for $8. It's a really good deal.

On another occasion, I got the Caprese sandwich and it was pretty tasteless. I had to use a lot of pepper. 

Other than that, it's a really pretty place to hang out (big windows) and the service is always fantastic.
author: Sam D.

description: I love getting a cafe at this place. It's so warm to have a cafe this cold season.
author: Michelle H.

description:
Cool neighborhood cafe. Chill vibes. Customers usually working on stuff (I usually come here to "work from home" 1 or 2 days a week). Sometimes it gets a little crowded, but most people won't mind sharing a table if you ask.

The art inside changes from time to time and seems to be from local artists. The food all tastes very wholesome and filling. Coffee is pretty good (De La Paz beans). Owner seems like a nice guy that seems to care about the atmosphere of the place and the neighborhood (has a fundraiser for a parklet out front).

I dig this place. And best of all its only 2 blocks from my apt!
author: Mike C.

description: My favorite coffee shop in the neighborhood. Friendly staff and surprisingly good food. A little on the more expensive side but well worth it. Strong WiFi makes this place a go-to for any occasion!
author: Mike  C.

description: Great food but SUPER SLOW SERVICE!!! Went for breakfast and there were no other customers and yet it somehow took 35 minutes to get my eggs!! And they served my girlfriend her oatmeal after 10 minutes, so she had completely finished her meal before I even got mine...
author: Daniel S.

description:
If you are coming here for anything other than coffee, I would suggest going elsewhere. I hadn't been to mercury in awhile because I was disappointed with their service the first time I went, but a coworker said their soup was good, so I decided to give them another try.

It took them 20-25 minutes to ladle soup in a bowl and make a side salad. The soup was fine, but totally not worth the long wait. Not impressed with my welcome there either. Coffee is pretty good, but service? Meh.
author: Audrey W.

description: Great place.  Great coffee.  Great food.  Friendly staff.  I only wish that they paid more attention to the music volume; it's way too loud.  Not really "background" music.
author: Thomas V.

description: Nice! Drip coffee made to order includes beans from Ethiopia and Rwanda! De La Paz coffee beans. I love the airy open space and huge window walls that open up to let abundance of sun and vibe of the Octavia street in. A lively, positive place!
author: David K.

description: Had the tuna salad sandwich and it was delicious! It comes with a small side salad, which was also very tasty. Their iced mochas are good as well.
author: DeAna G.

description: Easily a contender for best breakfast "sandwich" in town. Flaky biscuit, poached egg, avocado and smoky bacon... awesome. Great French press coffee and service too.
author: Daniel S.

description:
I just moved to the neighborhood and I'm just a block away, so of course I'm going to love it.  However, just to make sure that they got that last star from me, the Mercury Cafe hit me with the perfect package for a neighborhood coffee shop:

* wi-fi that doesn't suck
* coffee that is very drinkable
* a laid back laptop/chilling vibe
* power outlets
* a campaign to put a parklet out on Octavia
* open late
* $2 PBR (yes they serve beer)
* tasty caprese sandwiches

This alone is good enough for a 5 star cafe near me, but to top it all off they have a most delicious breakfast sando - called the egg mcmercury - which is made on a home made biscuit (not a bagel) with poached eggs (not microwaved).  This is my new weekend favorite breakfast.  My only challenge will be not wearing it out...
author: Travis B.

description:
Mercury Cafe could easily feature in an eHarmony ad:  It's got the bright bay windows opening on to Octavia street-- the madness and light of a San Francisco Summer's day outside-- the rich smell of home brewed coffee-- and an interesting internal architecture that creates a few shadowed nooks for quiet conversation.    The staff is tatoo'd and hipster'd to the appropriate degree, and not a shade more.

Something I'd tell an earlier me, other than 'Don't move to Portland,' is that love gets harder as you age.    Or at least my experience of loving has.    When you're 25, your prime dating years yawn like an abyss in front of you, and all is easiness, and worn copies of 'The Unbearable Lightness of Being' read naked,  maybe with a fresh cup of coffee, to boot.

By comparison, dating in your 30's is like an Excel spreadsheet.    Do I detect in this person's smile the fatal glibness that ruined X?   Does this person's ambition foreshadow another fruitless year-long-chase like with Y?   That this person wants children so badly-- is this another taste of Z's incessant clinging to expectation?    How much can I expect this person to contribute, realistically, to household finances?   Do they seem to value their health?   Do they understand 401(k) investment strategies at a competent level?   Why the odd fixation on Polish food?

Quesions on questions, memories of memories,  and you have to fight all of this while being charming and answering questions and appearing fresh-faced and optimistic and present and pleasantly self-depreciating (because us slightly older folks can spot a poisonous narcissist a mile off) and all of this in real time, with no breaks.

So you can see why I insisted on having an ad-worthy stage for this particular drama.    Mercury did not disappoint.    The iced Americanos were deep, and cool,  and rich,  like a cup full of the Amazon night right there in front of you.   The staff were attentive but got the 'first date' vibe and kept their distance.     There was no rush.

I caught my eyes in reflection on the way out the door, when it was over.    They were the eyes of a disappointed person.    

I did not call or text, as is the privilege of cowardice.   She got the message.

The long and tedious task of lining up the next one begins anew.    I think I'll use the Mercury as my control location.   Love gets harder as you age,  but controlling the externals gets easier.
author: Brill S.

description: I wanted to bring my friend to try their great coffee. But the owner seems to be in a bad mood today... completely ignored us at first, then when the two of us ordered one coffee I can already see his facial expression changing. To top it off, he then informed me a new policy where you have to spend $5 to sit and use their Wi-Fi.  We left.
author: Philip Y.

description: I've been to this place several times and try to avoid it now. I've encountered lots of rude baristas, the music is usually way too loud, and the food is never good (definitely not worth the price). The coffee is pretty good though.
author: Jason N.

description:
Wow....no kidding the sandwiches are good. 

I needed to waste a couple of hours waiting for daughter's camp bus to arrive and snatch a parking spot before the rest of the parents, so parked myself here. First wanted to try the veggie chili but they were out....so the helpful server offered to let me try the lentil soup....and gave me a small ramekin full to taste! Could have made that my meal, but decided to go for the Caprese salad. Bread - warm and perfect. Tomatoes-unbelievably perfectly red and ripe...but not in a gross ewww supermarket kind of a way. Flavorful mozzerella. And the balsamic was a delightful addition...one I use at home but don't often get out at restaurants, let alone coffee cafe's.  

Even ran into a dude whose parents live literally 5 min from me in Oakland (I think he still lives there too) so Mercury gets even higher marks for bringin' on the small world vibe. 

I'll be spending much time here come fall when chorus starts back up and my chauffeuring duties resume.

WiFi slow: 6 1/2 min video upload = 166 min
author: Laurie H.

description:
Love this place!
They have great coffee and even better service.
The barista answered a bunch of questions about the quality of coffee they use, and how they make it.  Really felt taken care of.
They also have a really good vibe- great sunlight, really hip music.
Its my new place.
author: Ryan Z.

description:
To be a great cafe you only need to perform well on a few criteria, but you have to do them really well: good coffee, good service, and good atmosphere.

Mercury exceeds on all these. I always get their au lait (which is incredible by the way - creamy but never overpowering the base coffee - super smooth and never bitter), and make a great au lait you need great coffee. They always have a nice selection of beans to choose from and they make your drink to order.

The people working here are superb and know their coffee. Great service and nothing more you could ask for.

Lastly, the vibe is perfect. It embodies Hayes Valley with its laidback atmosphere - it's spacious, never too crowded (as long as it doesn't become TOO popular!), and a great place to hang out and try to get some work done. Always some music playing in the background and not really the conversational crowd that comes around which again, makes it a great place to get work done. Free wi-fi and power sources.

I've never had their food but my sources and instincts tell me they would be good. Count  on this being a great pit stop for coffee or to just hang out and read a book/be productive in a quiet environment. We need more places like this around SF - thank goodness we've got one here in Hayes Valley.
author: Willy C.

description: Portabella "sandwich" is awesome. Comes in a hour dog bun stuffed overflowing with mushrooms peppers onions and with a delicious sauce. The atmosphere here is a warm and service is great. Coming back for sure!
author: Dharam K.

description:
Twas the day before last
And I was out on a stroll
With a housemate lass,
Breeze sun and bowl
My stomach did awaken
While in the vicinity
My breath was taken
When I witnessed the divinity
Of the Mercury Cafe
On the corner stood proud
"That place is passe"
My companion said aloud
But much to her chagrin
Her comment I did not ignore
"F**K YOU I'M GOING IN"
And I strolled through the door
And up to the counter
Where there I would find
Such a fine encounter
That my devotion did align
To the swashbuckling lad
Who pleasantly took my order
Outlandishly clad
And quite a performer
Quip after quip
And laugh after laugh
I wondered of his script
And if he was paid time and a half
For making me want
To come back for more
To observe this nonchalant
Esprit de corps
When order was placed
and down I was seated
I observed the haste
Until he completed
My sandwich on sourdough
With turkey, cranberry, cheese
All the while with a show
Of flourish, confidence, and ease
What a heavenly meal
That glorious structure became
So with an experience surreal
And appetite tamed.....




I left and would totally go back-Tip that barista too, he was the man.
author: Graham O.

description:
The laptop crowd really likes this place (in fact, you may have difficulty finding a table) and I can see why: free wi-fi, bathroom, power outlets, really good coffee (locally roasted organic, fair trade coffee from De La Paz), and quality eats.  Their sandwiches (mortadella, salami, turkey, tuna, caprese) are made with Acme bread.  They also have homemade chili, bagels w/ different spreads, pastries, homemade pie (currently one made with organic apples), oatmeal, organic granola, empanadas and beer on tap.  The café has wooden floors, wooden tables, wooden chairs and a heavy wooden door.  The walls are adorned with art and they play music that's not too annoying. 

* Tuna sandwich ($7.25): Made to order on your choice of bread, the sandwich tasted very fresh.  I liked the chewy roll, the dill and red onion in the tuna salad and the lettuce and tomato.  The sandwich came with a side salad of organic mixed greens, a tasty balsamic vinaigrette dressing and croutons.  

Everyone who comes here seems to hang out there to kill time or work.  Some people were reading novels, others studying, and some chatted with friends. Some of them clearly didn't have to worry about the 2 hour parking (try Fell if you want to be here longer than 2 hours).

I returned and the laptoppers were there in full force.  Yay!
author: Lolia S.

description: Update- up to 5 stars now! Music was nice n chill. And it's so bright and airy!
author: Grace K.

description:
Very solid little neighborhood cafe a few blocks from my home  Beautiful location with 20 ft ceiling, huge windows and white walls make the space open bright and inviting.  Has an old world charm that gives the feel that this place has been here forever (in one reincarnation or another). 

No vegan pastries today, the only pastries I saw were some regular scones.  Food review:

Roasted red pepper:  this was meant to be a sandwich, but you can turn any of their sandwiches into a salad, which is what I did.  I ordered it with extra cucumbers instead of feta and voila! Vegan. It came with hummus and the peppers and cucumbers were marinated. It was tasty.  I'm glad I got the salad dressing on the side because between the marinade and the hummus the salad had plenty of flavor already. It was very filling. 

Egg mcmercury. My husband had this.  He said it was tasty, the biscuit was good quality. 

Coffee and au lait.  Both good quality.  

I'd like to come back for lunch and try the chili or vegan lentil soup.  They also had about 6 brews on tap, which looked interesting.  The was plenty of room for a stroller, so this would a great place for me to come with my bro and his family. 

I'm stuck between giving this place 3 or 4 stars. I really like the vegan options, the atmosphere, the commitment to organic, but I'm just not sure if I'd come back on a regular basis.  Will try lunch and update my review.
author: Evelyn N.

description: I really love true, working-style cafes. Where it's possible to get a lot of work done because everyone else is on their laptop working. That's exactly what's going on here - there wasn't a single pair or group of people socializing, hahaha. Ah, nice and quiet, and the java is tasty here, too.
author: Mel G.

description:
Found my favorite study spot in SF...free wifi, great chill atmosphere, not too busy with people coming in and going out when I'm trying to get some work done, great variety of medium tempo music that doesnt make me sleepy or too amped, and I'm actually motivated by all the other people here getting their work done. Win!

P.S. Street parking isnt bad.
author: Jayme N.

description: Wow 4 star review average ?!!? For what ? A slightly crummy place with pretty bad food. I wonder what people think is good food nowadays ... I ordered a couple of sandwiches... both were below average and just barely edible. Coffee was below average. Not coming back here.
author: Vin A.

description: Coffee is great and I really like the big windows, let's in a lot of sunlight. Free wifi so it's a nice place to grab a cup of coffee and a snack and work. Usually come in the morning and there is rarely a line.
author: Amanda C.

description: Went for a cup of coffee to go. Brought my own travel mug and after I paid $2.75 and dropped the quarter change in the tip jar she informed me she would only fill it up part way because it's only a 12 oz coffee. My jaw dropped as I asked "for 2.75?"  She simply said yes, and gave me back my cup with her approximation of 12 oz in it. Normally I receive a discount for bringing my own cup, and I have never had someone only fill it part way. What's an extra 3 or 4 oz of coffee? I live in the neighborhood and usually go to another cafe for coffee. After this service, I think I will walk out of my way next time to go to my normal place.
author: Sacha I.

description:
I really wanted to like you, Mercury Cafe. Your ambiance is adorable -- from the outside, or if you luck out and get one of the big tables. You seem kind of mediterranean-funky, and you serve de la paz coffee.

But in the final measure, for somewhere I've trekked to from civic center, i don't really think it's worth it. There are cuter cafes out there. There is definitely more responsive service out there. There are cafes that have more ambient music selection. The dessert options here are terrible, which is my favorite reason to go to a cafe.

For a better cup, go to Blue Bottle or Ritual. For better desserts and ambiance, go to Arlequin cafe or La Boulange.
author: Asaf K.

description:
From Chicago, went to SF for a week, ended up eating breakfast here three times in that week. Its great!

Seems like a locals place, unassuming, but really great coffee compared to the other places around hayes we had breakfast at. Quiet as all hell, but not library quiet, just relaxed. I had a pastrami or something sandwich one day, which was perfect, with a perfectly dressed salad, and the double egg mcmercury the other two days which are delicious. Great meals.
author: Mork M.

description: I just walked by this place and didn't even know about it but I went in and ordered a turkey sandwich and organic lemonade thinking that it would be pretty generic.  But I was so pleasantly surprised. That was possibly one of the best turkey sandwiches I had and it was packed with turkey. The lemonade tasted fresh and was not overly sweet like so many other lemonades are. I would definitely go back if I'm ever in the area.
author: Christine V.

description: Not impressed with my welcome into this establishment.  I guess they are confident enough in their locals they don't need to try to impress a newbie wandering in.  Coffee was not hot enough, but music was good and the fresh scone was delicious.
author: April M.

description: My initial assessment is it's a great place! I grabbed two egg mercury and I thought it was delicious. I paired my breakfast with a Big City coffee which was great blend of coffee. The place is great place to just sit, hang-out, drink a cup of joe and relax or study. Anyway, the internet service is available and the signal is excellent. I'll be hanging out here again.
author: Donn D.

description:
Coffee is good, food is surprisingly decent - homemade and with good ingredients, but I think they need to rethink some of their prices.
I don't want to dis Mercury because it's my closest coffee shop, they do a pretty good job, and I don't want them to go away. I'm writing this review because I would come here everyday if it weren't for the $3.50 small cup of coffee. It's too much. When blue bottle is that close and $1 less, it's a problem. Mercury's coffee is good, but not that good. Also scones are like $4 even when they are a day old. c'mon. Not everyone in this neighborhood is pulling 200k/yr. Can we try not to alienate other potential regulars?
I feel like they're trying to pay for all the people that camp there all day on their laptops - for them maybe that $3.50 cup of coffee is a deal. Not fair to the rest. Props for the KPOO benefits and for remaining generally unpretentious. The staff is always really pleasant too even though it seems to be a bit of a revolving door. I don't know if that's a reflection on the owner or the job market.
author: Elle L.

description:
Great place to go if you wanna grab a cup of joe and be able to work/study in peace. The music selection is great and is just the right at the right level. It is not too loud where you cannot concentrate on what you need to do.

The soups are to die for. Both the Red Lentil and the Vegan chili are bomb. The bagel(s) are also great (they don't burn them, toast them just right and add just the right amount of cream cheese).
author: Briggs S.

description:
After coming here several times recently to study, I realized that I needed to add it to my list of study cafes.  Why?  Because it's kind of perfect.  

When I leave the confines of my room to study (yes, including Friday nights.  LOFNOTC is totally me!), I've discovered that Mercury Cafe is my go-to place.  It has large and small tables that are great for me to work on, large windows that let in plenty of light, and while I don't bring my laptop, most people do, and there are plenty of outlets for work (and free WIFI, I hear).  

I've only had tea here, mostly because I go so late in the afternoon that taking a coffee will probably keep me up until 3-4 a.m.  But maybe I'll take one next time I go... in the morning.

Otherwise, the crowd is chill, and I rather like the atmosphere.  No pretentiousness, the barista's friendly (and thankfully accommodates my need for a saucer to put my teabag :D), and I love how, one of these days, I can grab a beer instead of a tea and chill out.  Overall, it's got a relaxing atmosphere that's conducive to not-too-pressured studying.

Plus, I always time it so I can hit up Miette for its French macaron happy hour on my walk home . . .  :D
author: Jeanne Y.

description:
Ok I am a fan. I actually enjoy this place a lot. I moved to the neighborhood recently and this little spot just struck me as ... well home. A few big tables and a bunch of little tables, free wifi, good selection of coffee. It's a little slow but I come here to chill out after work and work on stuff. You can also grab a beer and a sandwich. Sandwiches are a bit pricey but tasty. I have had the roasted red pepper (basically a bunch of humus some roasted red peppers and some greens). It was quite good. Their scones are pretty good as well. Overall a great place.

They take creditcards but prefer cash, as their sign says. I think this is the nicest sign that says, "Hey we get charged a fee everytime you make a credit/debit purchase, so please don't take 3% of our coffee sale" I got to give them props for being polite about it :)
author: Greg G.

description:
Had a good experience with lunch: 
Red pepper sandwich with feta, lettuce, and tomato on wheat. Tasted great and fresh.

Quite a few folks on laptops enjoying coffee. Seems like a quiet place to enjoy some coffee on a sunny afternoon. Will have to return!
author: John B.

description:
I stopped into Mercury after finding it in the listings on Yelp for being vegan friendly.

It's a great little place with a decent amount of seating. One huge bonus is the abundance of power outlets for laptops and the free Wifi with no password. So, it had that going for it before I ever ordered.
