I ordered the vegan chili with chips and guacamole. It was 7.50 and very filling and tasty. They warned me that the guac was spicy and the guy who was making it talked about how he burned his hands on the jalapenos. So, bonus points for the warning and for the super fresh and spicy guac. I'll definitely be stopping in there more often.

Next time I think I'll try the red lentil soup or maybe the roasted red pepper sandwich. They both sound delicious.
author: Robert M.

description:
Great spot. Very chilled out vibe. Not that big. All espresso shots are double, which makes for some jittery work sessions. Like many coffee shops in SF, this place is filled with people on laptops, which I personally enjoy.  It just may not be the best for a large gathering of boisterous comrades.

There's a secret little room/table upstairs! No outlet up there, but great way to perch above everyone else and pretend like you're important.
author: Nikhil N.

description:
I'm a local and I tend to spend a lot of time on cafes, those that are good I make regulars. This place gave me mixed feelings.

The food: Ok so far I tried a sandwich that came with mixed greens. The holiday. It was ok nothing special, but that stood out, it's a cafe and they don't specialize in it.  The coffee was tasty strong but not super bitter. 3stars

The staff/service: The service is avarage, they're nice, they great, but are not very attentive. The music like was mentioned in another review is a mixed bag of genres depending on the barista, which is fine cause I like different types of music. But it was blasting!!! It felt like a club rather than a cafe, I could barely hear my own thoughts. I'm here trying to work, read or even talk to someone next to me I shouldn't have to be yelling.  The owner/manager should let the barristas know what the maximum music blasting level should be. When I asked him to turn it down, he seemed annoyed, and turned it down a bit. I sat down and had to politely ask him to turn it down again, which he did, it's still a bit loud. I shouldn't feel like it's unpolite to ask him to turn it to a reasonable level like they have it at most cafes.  I could hear it through my headphones. He wasn't rude but wasn't happy about my suggestions, the guy with the long brown hair could learn to be more aware that it's not a club/bar. He did turn it down more when he noticed I was on yelp haha. There was a girl barrista last time I came that was playing different music but didn't blast it as much. 2star 

The ambiance: The seating is average, lots of little tables packed in together. The art and arrangement is ok. It looks a bit old and worn down, it could use a good cleaning and a paint job. Overall it's a good spot to sit at and work on but again without blasting music, and a bass that makes my chair vibrate. I liked the music but not the loudness. The place looks meh. It has outside seating which is nice a bit addition so they get, 3stars

I'll give them another try and see if they improve. This is all things that they could use to improve their business and bring more customers. I'm sure people get turned off when things like this happen.
author: Juan C.

description:
a bit slow .... waited 10 min to order and the whole time I have been standing at the cash register.  
so I left.
I've been here a few times and I have up say never impressed by their service, attitude, or food.  
heading back to arlequin!
author: Mabel F.

description: Great french press coffee, good lattes, free wi-fi, lots of seating, homemade pastries  made every morning on site, dog bowl of water at the entrance, good sandwiches. Drop in here often. Good coffee place!
author: Jennifer C.

description: Had a great latte and bagel on my first visit here.  Service was very good, plenty of tables, wifi, and outlets. Lots of good choices for food that I am looking forward to trying.
author: George S.

description:
I just finished my second sandwich of theirs--the caprese, and I LOVED it. This cafe is completely unassuming, in fact I lived in the neighborhood for 2 years and never dropped in until now. 

The sandwiches (I had the turkey and the caprese) are amazing for such a small cafe. They're probably a little on the pricier side of sandwiches but I understand why, everything's fresh and they're big! I'm looking forward to trying out more types of food.

I'll definitely be coming back more often.
author: Diana C.

description: Stopped here as I was walking up toward Haight-Ashbury. I bought a sandwich that was twice as much food as I anticipated. Very friendly staff, chill atmosphere, and DELICIOUS food!
author: Rob H.

description:
People don't wear earbuds in this cafe because the music played is top notch hip shit. Love it! I really like the veggie chili, it's actually quite spicy. I find a lot of spicy food in this city is rather bland, so it makes me happy to find a healthy bowl of chili with a real kick. 

Yeah, other than that, everything everyone else who gave five stars said, I'll likely agree with.

They accept credit cards, but support them by paying in cash.
author: Stephanie M.

description: We stopped by here for a cup of coffee. Great coffee, friendly staff, fast service. There's a decent amount of seating as well. We didn't try the food but they have a nice selection of breakfast items, sandwiches, salads, and pastries.
author: Diana G.

description: Came here this past Sunday and was chatting with the barista. It came up that it was my birthday weekend, and later in the meal he brought by a surprise Snicker doodle cookie. Very thoughtful, five stars!
author: Nitin C.

description: Perhaps it's nice if you want to stay a while or eat. But if you are just in need of a quick cup, steer clear. My $3.50 pour over (the only brewed option) took several minutes to prepare (!) and then arrived both lukewarm and weak. I wouldn't chance it again.
author: Joe N.

description: Good service but they try a new coffee brand and it's pretty bad. Food ok but a bit expensive for portions size and quality.
author: Gal M.

description:
In it's own category with all the other cafe's-- this place deserves all five stars. The employees are all friendly and nice. The decor is cute and ever changing as they feature art from different locals on the walls. They use De La Paz beans and offer a variety of regions for drip coffee.

Great breakfast basics. Oatmeal, bagels with toppings, granola. All which are delicious. Weekends-- the Eggs McMercury are really satisfying and come out fast.

Lunch time- they offer a variety of sandwiches with a small side salad for under 10 bucks. You can turn any of these into full size salads instead. Their soups are really tasty and satisfying.

The things that really makes this place work is that their produce is really, really fresh and most if not all their stuff is locally sourced.

Free wifi as well! (But, don't be the dicks that take up whole tables for hours with one cup of coffee)

So happy this is my little neighborhood coffee shop. Please come and support and donate to their parklet efforts.
author: KA K.

description: I stopped here mid-afternoon for coffee and a sandwich and to check email before a meeting nearby. The coffee was very good, and I appreciated having a list of available coffees and a description of their flavor notes. If you're used to drip coffee, be aware that they only do pour-overs here, with the accompanying higher prices. The sandwich was also very good, with fresh ingredients, and there was a generous helping of salad with vinaigrette. Wifi worked well, and most tables seemed to have an outlet very close at hand.
author: Michael B.

description:
This is a great place to relax, do some work, hang out with friends.  They have good coffee, great sandwiches, wonderful pies, scones and croissants (baked by the owner), and wine and beer.  

It's small, comfortable and fairly clean; the wireless is free.  The counter staff are all nice, some of them are more on the ball than others, but no one is rude.  I've been here a number of times, and I find myself staying for hours.
author: R -.

description:
Order: Salami sandwich - 2 pieces of bread, salami, lettuce, some spread, wheat bread, and a small side salad of lettuce and balsamic vinegar.

I'd give it 2.5 if that was an option.

Strike 1 - $9.00 for an underwhelming salami sandwich

Strike 2 - It was 2 in the afternoon, not crowded or busy at all, and my sandwich took 20 minutes. A sandwich. And there were two people behind the counter, 1 to make the food, the other to make the coffee and tend the register. Really? He did find time to chat with one of his friends who had come to the counter though. Twice.

Strike 3 - I sat at a table that someone had sat at earlier, it was near the open window and nice outside. There was an empty water bottle, used glasses, napkins, some spilled water and a plate. I'm not picky and can wait for a clean up, and I assumed (falsely) that with it not busy they would easily be out to take care of the mess. No big deal. WRONG. On two separate occasions the employees came out to take care of other things but they for some reason didn't want to take care of the table I was at.

At one point, she straightened up the table directly next to me.

I had even put money into the tip jar at the start of the meal. Disappointed.
author: Jeff W.

description:
I wanted really badly to like MC, but since when is it standard practice to make an iced latte by dropping 3 ice cubes in a hot latte 2 seconds before handing it to me? And when I ask you to maybe put it in a bigger cup with more ice so the bottom wouldn't be hot while the top develops a layer of melted icewater, maybe you could even wipe down the new glass before handing it to me? Hate to sound entitled, but I shouldn't have to wipe down my entire hand after grabbing a glass handed to me. 

Customer service fail, but +1 star for a good caprese sandwich. Seeing as I could make a caprese sandwich at home, though, I'll pass on you, MC.
author: Ann H.

description:
My last two visits have been amazing. The barista is so warm and friendly. He spent the entire time singing and dancing to really amazing hard rock music. 

Coffee was great, too! 

Two thumbs up.
author: Elen A.

description:
If you come here hoping to find a bustling neighborhood coffee shop, you might think you walked into a zombie mausoleum, what with everyone so into their laptops they can barely be bothered to notice you sitting down at their table.

It is a great place to work, light spilling in from the huge windows all around, and a great place to watch the people and cars go by as you stare into space for inspiration. Great chilled vibe that doesn't distract from your work. One caveat: the WiFi, while free, is paint-dryingly slow.

Food and drink here is good quality, and more or less your standard organic fair-trade coffee shop fare. It's a bit on the pricey side: $7 for a soup, $8 if you want a piece of bread on the side (Really? $1 for a *slice* of bread?). Sandwiches or salads are $9. 

That being said, their customers tend to hang out for a loooong time, so they sort of have to make up for that with higher prices. If only their WiFi was faster and more reliable, I'd "work from home" there, even though my apartment is just a block away.
author: Bing W.

description:
Best people to plug ratio in the city. Unheard of. 

Also has great coffee, people and granola.
author: Kristen B.

description:
Vibe:  Relaxed.  Good music, and patrons are extremely friendly.  GIGANTIC windows that let in light and warmth, and when open -- air. 

Drink:  This place not only has delicious, individually prepared de la Paz coffee, but they have House kombucha, and fresh squeezed OJ.  They also will refill your cofee for only $1!!  I really love their Rwanda coopac coffee, which is so smooth I don't even add milk even though I normally take milk.  Did I mention they have $2 PBR bottles and they have several beers on tap that are only $3 during happy hour?  

Food: The fact that they're not serving avocado right now is awesome.  Why is that good?  It's out of season, and these guys do local and organic.  Their sandwhiches and salads are filling and delicious on Acme bread for $7-8.  For a cheaper option, build a bagel sandwhich ($2-3).
author: Jaime R.

description:
The Product: I had their Sumatra blend coffee which was a bit earthy and nutty, but it did have a little bit of sourness to it. I'm not sure if that's how it's supposed to taste, or if something went wrong with the batch, but it wasn't pleasant. Also, it cost $2 for a pretty small, maybe 10oz, cup. Maybe I'll try another blend the next time I go.

The Venue: Definitely a study cafe. Near the front door and windows there are four dining tables with four chairs to each. Along the side there is a long bench that flanks about seven small tables, along with four other small tables off towards the center (that makes about eleven small tables). Each of these small tables comfortably seat one person's laptop, drink, and other work, though some of them have an extra seat so that two people can cram in. There aren't enough outlets here if it gets packed, but you'll most likely be able to get access to one of the plugs.

Overall: Great service, great study cafe, but the coffee I could be better and cheaper. If I find myself there again, I'll try another blend.
author: Gun-Ik P.

description:
I had my first celebrity sighting here!  

That's more of me bragging than a review....  So let's get to it:

When I tire of the view from my window, feel like my room is too cold, or just get bored sitting alone, I come out to Mercury Cafe for their calm but social atmosphere, good coffee, tasty food and strong wi-fi connection.

With outlets a-plenty your laptop will never be in need of juice and since the place is packed with about 20 tables, you'll rarely share and if you do, people are nice.

I'm not a huge fan of coffee shops for work, there usually seems to be something that distracts me: loud music, a pod of chicks, too hot, too cold, slow wi-fi, no outlets, the list goes on.

At Mercury, however, I don't have any of those problems, making this my ideal coffee shop for an hour or two of work.
author: Nathan M.

description: I used to have a painting studio space in the storage room above the bar years ago when the cafe carried a different name. Now this bright spacious cafe gallery is tended by a lively barista glam pirate who makes the meanest mocha in town.
author: Michael J.

description:
What a gorgeous day
To sit at a bright cafe
And get some work done!

Yes! Seasonal food
And delicious drip coffee
Mellow music, too.

New favorite cafe?
I definitely think so!
(Bonus: happy hour!)
author: Hannah L.

description: Just came here today to use my Carrotmob voucher to help Mercury Cafe build a parlet. The tuna sandwich was one of the best I've had in the city.  And the oatmeal cookie was absolutely delicious! I'm definitely going back!
author: Nisha G.

description:
I have been to Mercury 3 times -  twice in the Summer and once last night for a friend's art show opening.

Mercury is a great spot to stop for a drink (draft beer or one of many soft drinks) on a Summer's day while window shopping on Hayes Street. It's a block away from the busier cafe's so it's like you can get a spot to sit and if you're lucky you can be by the giant windows which are amazing when they are opened on a warm day.

Really nice, quiet-but-not-too-quiet atmosphere and friendly staff.
author: Spencer H.

description:
The best way to describe mercury cafe is "fresh". 

The coffee is served drip on-demand, and you'll wait a little bit longer than a starbucks for your coffee to be ready, but I really appreciate it. All of the food is very light, the sandwiches, salads, bagels, etc; and quite good!  The huge windows which constantly shed natural light inside scoff at the need for the lights hanging from the ceiling. The music in here is always refreshing, with Radiohead often on the playlist.
author: Mike C.

description: What you'd expect from breakfasty food at a cafe. Nice atmosphere.
author: Eliza D.

description:
Ok, I had a mortadella sandwich yesterday, and it was fantastic. Delicious meat, fresh vegetables, and served on fresh Acme bread. I was holding back the last star, as a matter of principle, but now they fully deserve 5 star status!

Good coffee, good food, friendly service, and FANTASTIC LOCATION.
author: neil c.

description:
There were a few reasons not to leave my apartment today:

- It was pouring rain
- I had a slight headache*
- I slept in later than planned**

But I rallied, and my reward was Mercury Cafe. This place has rainy weather written all over it: plenty of seats, large windows to gaze outside, free wifi and really, really good sandwiches.

My turkey on acme wheat bread, with a generous amount of hummus, was divine. Salad served on the side, warm americano taken to go. It was very much worth the trip.

* Which had nothing to do with too many vodka tonics at Bootie/DNA. No relation whatsoever. Move along.

** Might have been caused by asterisk one. Just saying.
author: Jason B.

description:
One, I lov the each individual grinding dripping cup of coffee.
Two, I lov the great moist and tasty but vegan muffins for 2 bucks.
Three, I lov the great Acme bread Mortadella sandwich.
Four, I lov the nice service, clean, roomy and cozy seats.
And,
Five, I lov the eazy goin' neighborhood and I always find a parking on upper Page.

5 star for Mercury Cafe!
I say...... the best free Wifi cafe in the city!
author: Nobu K.

description: Coffee is really good.  Free wifi, pricey sandwiches but good. Popular place, lots of hipsters.
author: Virlie B.

description:
Mellow, as in in you can *actually* get work done.  The employees are pleasant. 

I enjoyed a yummy little glazed lemon cookie there the other day,, delicious!! I would come again just for that.  
 It does seem they are lacking a bit in the sweets department, which is a necessity if you stay there long enough!  

Overall, a good find!
author: Ashley H.

description: The coffee is the best in the neighborhood, in the neighborhood of excellent coffee! And the freshly made raspberry scones are to die for. Always friendly service, wifi, outlets, and voila. This is my pick for best coffee shop in Hayes Valley.
author: D F.

description:
The place is airy, has net, coffee is good, parking is descent, pastries allright...
but, the lack of last 1 star is for lack of good attitude, every time 
I come to this place, the help is sort of snobby cold as if they are doing 
you a favor...weird...
author: Alex W.

description:
whoa whoa a coffee shop that opens past 8pm? free wifi with power outlets. cheap coffee ($2 for drop) and what? middle eastern theme? tall ceiling. huge windows.
their coffee is even good (i'm drinking it right now.) 

ok i'm gonna station myself here for the rest of the summer.
author: Te R.

description: Fantastic coffee shop to get work done or meet with your teammates to collaborate. Super simple menu, French press coffee is pretty good . They have some cool art as well.
author: Sujata M.

description:
Pros:
-beer and tea are very good

Cons:
Wifi connection is very bad, don't expect to get anything done.
author: paul V.

description:
According to Foursquare, I've been here eighteen times in the past six months (during one of which I was out of the country), so I've tried pretty much everything on the lunch menu. You can't go wrong with the avocado sandwich, caprese sandwich on a deli roll (a must!), or the vegetarian chili. 

For coffee, my go-to was the Rwanda, but they don't have that anymore, so I'm still trying to find a replacement. Their espresso drinks are also consistently good. I do find their scones to be overpriced at $3 each, and their bagels have way too much cream cheese on them. 

It's bright and sunny with zippity wifi (that sometimes goes out), plenty of power outlets, and good music.
author: June L.

description:
Come here to be loved.  The super attentive, super approachable, super nice staff just oozes warmth even on the coldest, wettest, greyest, San Francisco days.

The food (including the scones) is made fresh in the Cafe and is wonderful.  Highly recommend the vegetarian chili unless you are heading to an office you share with other people...

Atmosphere is okay with lots of twentysomethings staring at Apple laptops.

Coffee is above average although they use a pre-made chocolate mix in their mochas for a reason that is beyond me.
author: David A.

description: Huge windows for lots o' sunlight and great ratio of outlets to people. The huge table right by the door is awesome for spreading out all your papers  and there always seems to be space to plop down with your laptop. I get ridiculously productive here for some reason.
author: Kevin L.

description:
A perfect symbiotic relationship with Straw next door.  We had 45 minutes to kill and Straw's host suggested we wait at the cafe and they would call us over.  Sounds good on a cold rainy night huh?  Yup.

We ordered some beers, hot coco and two slices of pie since the first was so good.  Nice place to hang out if you had your mac book but I kinda felt like I clashed with those people who did have them out.  We were obviously divided amongst the folks who were waiting for dinner and those who weren't.
author: Rosalind S.

description:
I will admit that I was pleasantly surprised how much I love Mercury Cafe.  I thought that I would try it once and probably never go back but this is my go-to local coffee shop now.  Conveniently right around the corner from my apt.  I don't know why I waited 4 months to try this place out.  On a gorgeous day like today, they open their huge windows so it feels like you're outside.  Decor is very simple, atmosphere is low-key with a little music in the background.  Plus, free wifi.  Perfect.

I was absolutely hesitant about their coffee but it's pretty damn good!  Not too bitter or strong.  I personally like the latte.  I keep going back for more.  It's consistently good which, to me, is key.

Their sandwiches are quite tasty, too.  I was expecting to be somewhat disappointed but I have to admit that I find myself going back their for more than coffee.

Prices are decent.  My latte is a little over $3.  Sandwiches are $7-$8.

I just found about their happy hour.  This is dangerous for me....
author: Lisa K.

description:
Mercury cafe is the best. There coffee selection is decent and they do drip by the cup. They make most of the food in-house and much of it is organic. They also have about 6 beers on tap. 

The staff is friendly and attentive. The owner Nick is fantastic and involved with the community. He is currently raising funds to get a parklet in front of the cafe. This will be nice for drinking your latte outside. 

Currently there is only inside seating but the atmosphere inside is pleasant with many people doing typical coffee shop things like reading the newspaper, studying, chatting, etc. There are also large windows that let a lot of light in. It's a very nice space.

Whenever I need something quick to eat or a latte I usually go here. Highly recommended! Try the house made pie!
author: Jeff D.

description:
What a great space! The side that faces Octavia is almost all windows, half of which can be opened to let the cool San Francisco breeze whip by the cookie shelf and magically lift them up and into my mouth. The combination of the natural light, white walls and wooden seats and tables make a great work-from-home, studing or reading atmosphere.

The coffee is single drip and I recommend the one that has hints of cherry. I forget the name, and I could barely taste the cherry, but the overall flavor was tasty (as suggested by the Barista when asked what her favorite one was).

There IS free wireless but it was somewhat spotty the day I used it. I think I lost signal every 20-30 minutes. Not the end of the world, but if you're doing anything where that might interrupt your work, you might want to invest in Xanax.

The only downside (and this con is more for me, not universal) was the selection of coffee condiments. With only milk, 1/2 & 1/2, and soy as options and no Splenda in sight, I was left without being able to create my ideal cup.
author: Jared S.

description:
Currently my favorite coffee shop in San Francisco (and I spend a lot of time in them!).    Here is what it has going for it:

1.  Fantastic De La Paz coffee
2.  They single drip their coffees
3.  La Marzocco espresso machine.  They both know how to use it and they have the beans for it!
4.  Super friendly baristas
5.  great, relaxed atmosphere with tons of lights and plenty of seats
6.  plenty of outlets
7.  Good food (bagels, sandwiches, great empanadas, a wicked spicy vegan chili, etc.)
7.  free wi-fi
8.  they are relaxed with you spending a fair amount of time working there.  Just keep buying stuff and tipping your baristas!
author: yohans w.

description:
I came here today for the first time with two of my best friends. The environment was very chill like any other cafe. Everyone seems to come here for a cup of coffee and a place to sit to work on their papers lol. It's a nice place to just sit and talk.

Sandwiches:
Tuna - Pretty good
Salami - Pretty good

Each sandwich comes with a side of salad topped with balsamic vinegar. I thought the vinegar was a nice touch to the salad. I probably  had better tuna sandwiches elsewhere but overall it was still pretty good. I mean my friend, who despised tuna for about a little over a decade now, actually thought the tuna sandwich was pretty good lol. The sandwich and salad were good, but I was a little disappointed after they told me that they were all out of wheat bread. 

Considering that I live halfway across town, I probably wouldn't travel all the way here to grab a bite of sandwich, but if I were in the neighborhood and wanted to chill with a friend, I would probably consider eating here again.
author: Annie T.

description: You know how you determine a good apple pie? By the crust! We were fighting to eat the crust, it was good! Hot coco on the side was even better minus the piece of paper I bit into that was on the bottom of my cup, eww. I was waiting an hour to get into Straw next door, they sent us over to Mercury to wait for our table.
author: Karen T.

description:
I've got to respond to Melanie's post.  The outlets were/possibly are on one wall, but they refurbished the place with a new wall-length bench and PLENTY of outlets (and free, simple wireless).  Also, the staff is always really friendly, approachable and helpful (albeit not the most ebullient or tattooed like you might find at Ritual).  They don't glare at you even if you've been there for 5 hours.

The coffee is excellent, but does take a bit of time.  For food, I would HIGHLY recommend the vegan chili.  I often make my own chili, but I can only dream of making it as good as Mercury's.  I was very pleasantly surprised when spoon hit tongue.

Mercury is my go-to spot to get some work done while enjoying great coffee and food.
author: Jay W.

description:
I absolutely love this place... I'm working on my laptop with my friend here almost every day and it is a great place: free wi-fi, tons of outlets and... the best Caprese sandwich i ever tired! I'm so addicted to it!!! 

LOVE IT!
author: Nastia R.

description:
They've got yummy sandwiches and a reasonable amount of selections of vegetarian stuff. 

They offer free wi-fi that's pretty fast.
author: Lo Y.

description:
great coffee, brewed on the spot.  (just as fresh as blue bottle but less pretentious.)  cozy but airy space with tons of windows--great for taking advantage of a nice day even if you have to stay in and "work."  pastries are unremarkable, except for the stuff they make in house which is delish, but all the rest of the food is fantastic.  super friendly folks.  fun rotation of art.  completely open wifi.  my only complaint (and it's not even a complaint, more just a fussy wish) is that they need some cuter furniture--it would really freshen/brighten the space.  

but really, this is the perfect neighborhood cafe.
author: tara w.

description:
Simple, wholesome homemade food. Fair prices - the kind where you're getting what you pay for in quality ingredients prepared in-house with care. Great ambience! Huge windows opening up to a tree-lined street. The perfect place to stop by for morning coffee or to sit for hours.

Most of all, great location .....except for being at a corner where everyone in the city passes but rarely stops. Next time you pass by Page and Octavia, take the time to stop into this peaceful oasis.
author: Ophelia W.

description:
I came here twice while staying with a friend around the corner.  The first time my man and I were hung over and it felt like we were ordering in slow motion.  I felt sort of like a jerk, but I was thinking as fast as I could.  They didn't have bagels because they'd run out, so I ended up ordering toast with my coffee.  And my dude got the last tiny little McMercury egg & cheese with tomato.  It was adorable, but tiny -- small, petite, itty bitty --  to the point that I felt guilty asking to share, and this made me a little bitter until I tried my toast, which was actually quite good.

The next time I came by to order a bunch of takeaway coffees at quite a normal speed.  Same hipster barista dude, still quite nice.  He has pretty tattoos.  Although he was playing "The Knife" during the day, which to me seems paradoxical ...  Anyway, the coffee was great both times.
author: Dave R.

description:
Ah, my favorite hayes valley coffee shop. Big tables, lots of outlets (on one wall, i believe). Free and reliable wi-fi. 

They single drip their coffee - which is awesome and tasty! 

The sandwiches are good. I've been meaning to try the vegan chili, but haven't had a chance - heard good things about it though.

Great place to study and people watch. Staff is super friendly.
author: Sarah A.

description:
Ah, I want so badly to give this place 5 stars... in truth, it deserves a 5*, but since Yelp doesn't really do footnotes, I'm forced to give it a 3. It pains me, because this place is adorable and unpretentious and the service is amazing-- they are extremely nice. 

But they messed up my order.

I ordered a Turkey sandwich and asked to substitute the tomatoes with avocados. I was beyond ecstatic when the woman behind the counter didn't charge me extra for the substitute (as many places are prone to). I then took a seat, I checked into every iPhone geolocation app that I own while I waited.

I was waiting for around fifteen minutes, which was a little annoying, but at the very least it built up the anticipation. I wasn't even going to complain about the time, but the cashier tossed in a free salad and an (amazing, delicious) chocolate chip muffin into my bag to make up for the wait. I giddily skipped off with my brown bag, already formulating a 5-star review in my head (I am apparently easily bribed by free muffins). 

Then I got back to my desk... and lo' and behold, tomatoes in my sandwich and no avocados in sight. So disappointing. I know it seems like a nit-picky thing, but it wasn't my order -- the order the cashier seemed to put effort into repeating back to me to ensure it was correct.
author: Sabrina M.

description: Decent coffee though a tad overpriced and not that amazing, served with nasty girl attitude! :) Free WiFi an good seating. The whole "we make coffee individually each cup" - is a bit of a gimmick. One selects the flavor and presto the gal behind the counter will grind the small batch of coffee and make a drip coffe for you. It all looks good, but in the end I found the coffee not that great, espceially at the cost.
author: Miklos P.

description:
Yet another one of those places in my neighborhood I've unintentionally avoided until recently. Heck, I still remember when this place was pretty much abandoned for like, three or four years. Now, as part of the new wave of hip, slightly upscale eateries to pop up around Hayes Valley, we have a new neighborhood coffee shop.

I have to admit, I'm big on both sandwiches and coffee, and while I do like the offerings at Mercury, they're actually a bit more expensive than some of the surrounding places offering similar products. Most of their sandwiches are around $8, and although they come with a little side salad they're pretty basic and small. And their coffee starts at $2. Up until we raised our prices at Peet's I always said I never like to pay $2+ for a cup of coffee ... and I still don't, actually. Still, Mercury's sandwiches and coffee ARE pretty good. And they have beer. On tap!

Seeing as it's a hip little neighborhood joint it's always pretty crowded with people plugged in to their MacBooks and whatnot, but when the place is as tiny as Mercury it's sometimes hard to find a seat, so if you want to sit down and enjoy your meal you might be out of luck on a nice day or a weekend. And oh man is it hot in there, too. Whew!

The staff here are very friendly though, and are genuinely helpful. No complaints here!

Still, with the price and the small space it's not really a place I'd want to hang out at as often. I still like Cafe Trieste down the street better, so I think for now I'll stick to that for my sandwiches, and since I get free coffee from work I can do without expensive espresso drinks. But if you live in/around Hayes Valley or Lower Haight you may want to give this place a try.
author: Will C.

description: Very nice staff/owner and the coffee is good.   The place is a little coffee shop with small tables for single 'swatters' and 3 larger tables that seat 4 people.  Free wi-fi, some outlets, good place to hang and not be bothered.   The food there is above average for a coffees shop.  The coffee is single brew, so will be little bit more than commercialized we will take over the world coffee shops.  They have sandwiches and 'coffee place food'.   Parking is best around Laguna or one of the small streets around it, then walk about 1 block.
author: H D.

description: Great cafe where most people tend to work or study - free wifi! On a nice day they open the big front window giving you a nice breeze. Had a delicious cafe americano and homemade scone!
author: Antonea C.

description:
Yummy coffee. Both drip and espresso are usually solid. Great workspace - big tables, nice lighting, free wifi. Although the tables in the back get a little depressing because of the lower ceiling, proximity to the bathroom, and distance from the wonderfully large windows.

Great happy hour specials on beer. Foods looks yummy, but I haven't tried it. I'm excited to go back and get one of their delicious-looking sandwiches. Seems like it would be a nice place to chill with a glass of wine, but I'm not sure that I saw any options.
author: Monica C.

description:
Though I haven't been able to spend as much time at Mercury lately as I used to, I'm very pleased to report that they've expanded their vegan options and have really grown into themselves! THANK YOU, guys, for getting hummus for the bagels. It is delicious! There's also a vegan chili, vegan cookies, good beer, and veganizable sandwiches. The coffee is great, and I really like that they've been experimenting with adding new blends. 

Another BIG thumbs up for leaving the power outlets open for us jobless or freelancing slobs and our laptops who would otherwise never leave our houses. Oh, and another one for the happy hour! Cheep beer! Oh, and thanks for the neat art. I've seen a lot of crap on cafe walls, and Mercury is a really great exception to that rule. 

Finally, a huge thank you to Nick and the staff at Mercury for letting some friends and I host a charity bake sale (to raise money for humanitarian aid in Haiti) at the cafe when we were rained out of our original location. They were extremely accommodating and gracious, and we are really grateful.

Support a great independent business owned and operated by some awesome folks, and hit up Mercury!
author: Jordan P.

description:
Great sandwiches on Acme bread.  I had a caprese.  The mozzarella was fresh and yummy, tomatoes juicy but firm and not drippy, and the bread of course awesome.

I had my usual standby, the decaf soy mocha, and it was tasty (none of the bitter coffee taste).  But I'm by no means a coffee aficionado, so you'll want to confirm for yourself.

They also have free wifi and plenty of electrical outlets where you can plug in.  Only downside is they close pretty early: they were turning away new customers as early as 6:30pm (on a Saturday, no less), though I hung out until around 7.
author: Brian T.

description:
This place is awesome!

Friendly service, good morning food and coffee, reasonable prices, free street parking.  Free wifi I'm using right now, many outlets along the wall.  I like the open layout, lots of light and space.  

Wish I could give it 6 stars.
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Great coffeeshop with tasty food. They make their coffee single-serving to order, which seems to be a common trend among all of SF's top-notch coffee joints. I tried the Ethiopian Sidamo last weekend which was right up there among SF's coffee greats like Blue Bottle and Philz.

The food is also great. I've tried the the tomato/mozzarella sandwich and the chicken sandwich, both were very good. They come with a nice side salad, which gives the illusion that you're eating healthy. 

It's a tad pricey, especially the coffee because it comes in such a small cup. But it's worth it for the taste, the atmosphere, and the free wifi. As an added bonus for us coffeeshop connoisseurs, there are plenty of power outlets!
author: Adam B.

description:
i'm editing my review after a very poor customer experience. the guy behind the counter ignored my drink order and combined two types of milk, despite me asking for something specific for health reasons. it was pretty odd. Next time I'll just cross the street and go to Ritual who always does it right when I ask.

Quality of service really depends on who you get at the register. This dude just wasn't nice.
author: Hello G.

description: Yay local cafe! I like coming here just to hang out, do some work, drink some coffee/tea/beer  (whichever I'm in the mood for), and look out at the street traffic from their huge windows.  It's a very chill environment, they sell a variety of food, and they have free wi-fi (always cool). It does tend to be packed full of people, so sometimes finding seats can be difficult. Overall it's an enjoyable place.
author: J.D. Q.

description: Had a slice of apple pie there today - it was the bees knees! Best apple pie I've ever had. The cappuccino was nice too.
author: Sankara G.

description: I met up with a friend here, so we needed a place where we could chill for a while. It was a sunny day, so the huge, open windows were perfect. I had the local kombucha they serve, which was awesome, but I can't say anything about the coffee. The people were nice and chill, was also good. If I'm in the neighborhood again, I won't mind going back.
author: Vero K.

description:
Pretty chill, and convenient location...and awesome free wi fi! tables are spacious, not too crowded on weekdays. a lot of cool art hanging around.

Has a little bit of an identity crisis, trying to be a lot of things... coffee, beer, pie, hummus, baked goods, empanadas, chilli, guacamole, pb&j, sandwiches,, lemonade (no italian soda tho!)... a little bit for everyone i guess!

less stars:
* music a little louder and more rock than i'd expect from a cafe...fine, except if someone calls you on the phone they can probably hear it!
* food's a little expensive.... 5 bucks for a parfait. 2 bucks for butter with toast. 3 bucks for baked goods. 1.75 for tea / 2.00 for iced tea...or maybe just feels more expensive during these "tough economic times"!
author: S V.

description: Super friendly. Free wifi. Big windows. Great place to get some work done.
author: Alex A.

description: I discovered this place on my way to Straw next door.  I was pleasantly surprised by the quality of their mocha.  Their coffee is all hand-dripped.  Their food menu looked pretty good and it seemed like a pretty laid back atmosphere.
author: Marleen C.

description:
If I had to pick one, this is definitely my favorite cafe in SF for the following reasons:
-Two floors of windows on two walls = lots of light and fresh air
-Great coffee (individual brew) (I haven't really had many of their espresso beverages)
-Sandwiches with fresh ingredients ($5-7)
-Two blocks away from my place
-Free and fast no-nonsense wi-fi
-Rarely crowded
-Friendly staff and easy-going local patrons (lot of older customers there to read the free newspaper)

Downsides 
-The traffic is a little loud (on Octavia)
-Closes at 8PM
author: G H.

description: What a great little find! I was on my way to a Hate Crimes talk at the LGBT Center and was trying to figure out where to grab something between the 71 bus stop and the Center -- and there was little Mercury Cafe. I ordered the first thing on the menu (avocado, cucumber sandwich) which was very tasty and topped it off with a great cappuccino (and I am terribly critical of my cappuccinos). Interesting group hanging out, all in their own little world but not in an unfriendly sort of way. A bit off my beaten path, but I will definitely be back.
author: Robert M.

description:
Good GOD, their sandwiches are amazing.  When we're feeling particularly lazy on the weekends we walk the whole half block to Mercury and order a sandwich and a coffee and enjoy the sunshine and good vibes.

Eat the mortadella.  It is so. goddamned. good.
author: Nils J.

description: Good place to spend an afternoon working: power, wifi, and coffee are good and unpretentious. The young lady who makes the sandwiches seems to always be upset about something or other and takes it out on the food. But don't let that get to you!
author: Dave G.

description: Great open air space with plenty of light and high ceilings. During the week days, it's mostly working people so there's not a lot of chatter, which makes it great to do just that (work). The staff is friendly and basically leave you alone after you order. The music they play here is awesome. The food and coffee/tea are really good. Just two complaints here: some of the items are a bit expensive ($6 for a slice of pie?) and sometimes they run out of what's on the menu. :/  I love it though. I've explored a bunch of places and this is my favorite coffee shop in Hayes/LowerHaight/Mission/Castro. Oh and the wifi is free and really fast.
author: Ramon S.

description: Im not sure why, but whenever I go into mercury, I feel a little bit disconnected. For you internet junkies (Im not commenting about their wifi connection) their wifi works just fine. The coffee is not bad, but it can seem somewhat dull at times. I'd give it 3.5 stars.
author: Vivek N.

description: I visited Mercury Cafe for the first time after reading Yelp reviews.  I had their Burundi drip coffee and Avocado sandwich in an organic everything bagel.  The coffee was excellent-smooth, aromatic and tasty.  the burundi coffee was recommended if you put milk into  coffee.  The avocado bagel sandwich was pretty tasty too-lots of veggies and generous amount of avocado.  i felt pretty healthy after gulping down my meal on a lazy weekend lunch.  What distincts Mercury cafe the most from other cafes in downtown SF is that it's very spacicous and has almost a 1:2 plug to table ratio (if you sit by a bench table, there is guaranteed a PC plug.)  the staff are also quite casual and friendly.  i would recommd this cafe if you want a change from the major coffee chains!
author: Susan C.

description:
I came in on a trip from la. It was the perfect spot to study and sip on amazing drinks. My soy latte was super tasty, and my jasmine tea was just as amazing. My favorite part of the trip had to be the friendly baristas and the amazing mini-peach cobblers. 

I love this place!
author: Erin N.

description:
Miracle scones and nice coffee, but I go for the scones. I find that it depends on who's making your cappacinno. And often I'm on my way somewhere so I'm just getting things to go. 

Great place to hang out and work.
author: Martha Sue H.

description:
The Mercury Cafe is a recurring habit for me when I need to crank through hours at the computer and out of the house.

Consistently delicious coffee, individual brews that can be tailored to the random needs of you ... friend, really tasty food (I am a fan of the rotating soup selection which is usually vegetarian and always affordable for cafe food), and great sunny windows.

The customers are an amicable bunch.  I actually made a good friend through a glancing social interaction.  Fancy that, interacting in meat space...
author: Laureli K.

description:
(I hope to move this to a five star review once the place has hit its stride.)

This is a great, sunny, airy place to work, drink yer caffeine, have a bite. Free wireless internet! Mighty Leaf teas! Fresh tasty food, though somewhat limited at the moment. With a more robust food menu, this place would be my Momi Tobi's for the work-day.

The name should unfortunately be the Phoenix Cafe, the way this space is constantly being reborn. I'd love to see Mercury stick around.

The Location: Octavia street is well trafficked, sure, but come on, you're sitting in a cafe in the middle of the second densest city in the US. The atmosphere of the cafe overwhelms the boulevard.

p.s. Great reading material--for some reason they have two issues of the Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society.
author: John F.

description: Nice little place. Low-key vibe, and the avocado sandwich I ordered was very good. Bread was toasted lightly, and the mixed greens side salad with a vinaigrette completed the plate well. Add the fact they have free wifi, and I enjoyed my experience here very much.
author: Bryan S.

description: Delicious lunch  with turkey, cranberries on wonderful bread.  We ordered the chili but too spicy, they gladly exchanged it for the Lentil soup that was outstanding.
author: Susan L.

description:
Great coffee house.  Good single drip coffee, and a realaxed atmosphere.  

Though I am here on a Sunday afternoon.  I am guessing that I would have little chance of finding a table on a Saturday morning, but that is just a guess.

I will be back, even though I had to walk 6 blocks to get here.
author: Travis S.

description:
Every Thursday is date night with my partner.  We've set it aside for us for years now.  We usually go out to a café in the afternoon and dinner in the night. At least one Thursday a month we try to find a new café to experience.  Last week we tried out Mercury café for the first time.  We were there for 2-3 hours.  They have a bunch of small tables set up along one wall with access to outlets and all the laptop folk sat along there.   They have free wifi.  We picked a larger solid table near the window. I like that there was room to spread my books and journals out and the table did not rock. We both had tea and fruit turnovers. The tea came in small white diner coffee cups. The kind of cup that says drink this fast and leave. However, the guy at the counter was very friendly and refilled the hot water whenever I wanted. Still, I like to have enough water/tea so that I can maintain my focus on reading or journaling or talking with my bf and not have an empty cup after a few sips. The café gets noisy easily. The table next to us had 3-4 people talking loudly and they completely filled the small space with their business meeting. Luckily we weren't trying to communicate just then and both turned our ipods on.  The other drawback was that there were small gnats flying about and some other kind of vermin, maybe fleas.  Really a lot of cafes in SF have fleas, but it's a terrible feeling to be out enjoying the café and have the little devils crawling up and down you.  I should have remembered to put some repellent on my cuffs.  It was an ok café experience, but not great, and we probably won't cross town again to return. Maybe I should do a summary because my review wandered a bit:
Pros: Well lit, friendly good service, hot water refills, comfortable tables, wifi, electric outlets, good music, tasty pastries.
Cons: small space--gets loud quickly, too small tea cups (tea pots would be best), not a cozy space.
author: Herschell L.

description: I was surprise that a small little coffee shop like this could make some unbelievably tasty sandwiches. They start with excellent quality Acme bread and stack it with a pile of fresh meat and vegetables. The cranberry turkey one and coppicolla was especially tasty. The pies are great too, full of fruit on a noticeably crispy crust. The food is not cheap by any means but the quality is definitely worth it.
author: Ed L.

description: Chill atmosphere, good coffee, tasty/healthy sandwiches and consistent Wifi! Music is mediocre, but otherwise a great cafe to get work done from.
author: Doris T.

description: This place is kind of amazing - as locally sourced and locally grown as you can find, with the soups, scones and pies (the blueberry is to die for) made from scratch. It's not fast food, so if you have bad timing and get there at the end of a rush, you'll have to wait a bit. Great sandwiches, with some good vegetarian options, too. The new parklet out in front is a great option for drinking a cappuccino, especially if it gets crowded inside with all of the computer junkies mainlining the free wi-fi. Finally, the staff ranges from great to awesome, just one more reason this is my favorite local cafe.
author: Bradly B.

description: Super friendly staff. I live less than a block a way and am in here almost everyday. Love their sandwiches and wifi for studying. Great neighborhood spot. There is usually a little bit of a line because they make all their food fresh to order. But it is worth the wait :)
author: Marie V.

description: Little spot at the bottom of the hill between Hayes and the Lower Haight. Vegetarian avocado sandwich on sourdough Acme bread was $8.75. It was good, and it came with a side salad of mixed greens tossed in a balsamic vinaigrette. The coffee was a tad disappointing for their claim of brewing every cup--sigh-- Four Barrel and Ritual Roasters has me spoiled.
author: Shira O.

description: I would never choose to go here based on the decor. It's really not cute or cozy or anything. But my caprese sandwich was great and the free wifi was reliable and I really liked the music (which was not too loud, either). Minor complaint: the side salad had a bit too much dressing on it.
author: Richa A.

description:
I was in town to go apartment-hunting (never an easy task) and needed a place to sit and work during the day. The Mercury Cafe wasn't incredibly easy to find (it's tucked in a corner of the street amongst a lot of traffic and few other noticeable landmarks), but once I found it, I was immensely happy with its service. 

The coffee is strong, but delicious and they offer refills for $1. Since I was basically homeless for those few days, I ended up getting two out of three meals a day at the Mercury Cafe. They have terrific selection of food (including breakfast food!), delicious and health-conscious sandwiches as well as a fabulous variety of drinks.

Luckily, they have free wireless and an abundance of plugs. It never feels to cramped in that cafe, which is probably because the tables are all situated just far enough from each other, so no one ends up feeling like they're working in each other's bubble. The chairs are comfortable, and it never gets too loud. 

I've spent entire days working in coffee shops before, but the Mercury Cafe had such a homey environment and friendly staff, that I kept going back every day I was in town.
author: Rachel B.

description: Their espresso drinks really improved in consistency over the past year, and their sandwiches are very good.  Nick, the owner, is super chill, and the staff he hires are generally very cool, and usually quite good baristi.  Wi-fi is good, so it makes my hot list!
author: Ari M.

description: I love love love this place. Free wifi. The coffee is great, the food is delish and ppl are awesome. What more could you ask for?
author: Krista D.

description: The sandwich was good, but it's 1:45pm (still lunch time) and yet wait was 14 minutes for my sandwich and there was only 1 sandwich ahead of my order. Clearly, if you need a quick sandwich, this is not the place!
author: Brian B.

description: The caprese sandwich is possibly the best and freshest I've ever had. Their coffee is made by the cup and will get you GOING in the morning. Also, their veggie chili is yummy and VERY spicy - great for a chilly day. Have always had a great experience at Mercury Cafe and you surely will too.
author: Tanya K.

description:
So the tea (Orange Dulce) was delicious...and served in a glass rather than a mug WHICH I LOVE! Then I hung out, used their free (no minimum purchase) internet, next to one of their numerous plugs. A few hours later, I got a sandwich. They have lots of vegan, veg, and meat options. Good sized sandwich, and a great deal considering it is all organic. Some soups and empanadas were available too, and scones, which looked good. 

The cherry on the sundae? My back tire of my bicycle was being stolen when an employee was coming to work, and he & the owner chased after him and got it back for me! (Having front AND back quick-release wheels is not always a bonus). Thanks Mercury Cafe! You saved my wheels, and made my belly happy.
author: M A.

description: Loved the avocado sandwich.  Nice atmosphere, convenient location.
author: Jen C.

description: Friendly barrista, lovely coffee. I had a wonderful cappuccino and my bf had a great mocha. They use locally roasted coffee beans and local artisanal chocolate as well.
author: Roberta B.

description: Great food, great ambiance, and they throw tons of benefits for local activist groups.  I can't speak highly enough for Mercury Cafe.
author: Dan S.

description: Mercury makes great sandwiches and coffee- they've got really good stuff. However, it's not cheap, and the staff is inevitably pretentious and somewhat rude. I live right around the cafe and have never walked away without at least one unpleasant comment from the folks here! However, they still have good lunch and lots of tables, so if you're ok with a bit of attitude it's a good place to go.
author: Alison D.

description:
I live up the street and have been yearning for an alternative to Momi Tobi's. I like Momi Tobi's atmosphere, but Momi Tobi's is too crowded and their coffee & baked goods are so-so. 

Mercury Cafe has amazingly awesome scones! Awesome as in good enough to go out of my way to get. It turns out the owner (?) bakes the scones and pie. I'm so looking forward to trying the pie. I was told that the co-owner makes the chili, so last night I staggered in from a long weekend in Seattle carousing with my boyfriend and wanting hot nourishment; it is certainly good, but needed some salt. The scones were better, but sadly, women cannot live on scones alone.  I hear the coffee is strong and tasty, so will be trying that next. 

Hopefully Mercury Cafe will do well. I look forward to many a lingering visit there.
author: Alex S.

description: The perfect, unassuming coffee shop that has everything going for it. Seems to attract only the very good looking, literate/bookish, witty, sexy-type.
author: Pax, Formerly Known As Rufus D.

description: Thank God something really good has come to this spot. Fantastic coffee and good sandwiches. Now I just have to drag my ass there for beer.
author: Ted F.

description: A pleasant cafe, with free wifi and a good amount of outlets, making it a food place to work.  Atmosphere is just OK, parking can be tough, but the people who work there are nice.
author: Corey C.

description: One of the best cafes in the city on a sunny morning. With my Economist and cup of coffee, sun pouring in through the giant windows... it doesn't get much better. Minus one point because the breakfast food selection is so limited, but if you are here to relax/read or work in a cozy atmosphere, this place is fabulous. My personal favorite in Hayes Valley.
author: Priya N.

description: Everytime I forget to buy coffee for the house I head to Mercury. It's right near my place, and I can still wear sweat pants without feeling like a creeper. This place has awesome drip coffee. I love their Kenya, but the Rwanda coopac lately has stolen my heart. I am not a vegan, but their vegan chili and vegan scones are quite succulent. It's also nice inside, to the extent that if I hung out in cafes, this would be the spot. All the folks that work there are very nice, but especially cheery is the young man with the long hair. I'm also partial to him because he makes the hummus, and the hummus is goooood.
author: Isabel L.

description:
This is a really short review as I was only in there for about four minutes this morning, but free wifi and, perhaps, the tastiest mocha i have EVER had leads to the five stars. I'm sure I'm totally jumping the gun on this one, but for first impressions i was happy.
Decor is about as bland as you get, but who ACTUALLY cares about that stuff? If the coffee is good, the place is good
author: Rumpel S.

description: I love this place. Great coffee, perfect location and nice people. It's starting to become my living room.  (Did I mention the home made PIES?)
author: Greg H.

description: Very cozy cafe!  Yummy and strong individually brewed coffee, awesome home baked scones/muffins (often vegan), free wifi and friendly service!  One of my favorite cafes to visit in the area.  Only downsides are they close early and no outside seating.
author: Melinda H.

description:
Everytime I come to SF to visit my gf, I always stop by Mercury for a quick cup of joe and a nice place to study. The free wifi, the good coffee, the big tables, the AWESOME artwork(that seems to be different everytime I come in here) are all fantastic aspects of Mercury. I love their homemade scones! tasty and fresh. The owner is always in here and he's very nice. As other people have said, the natural lighting of the place and big windows provide a nice open feel to the place. All of the employees are pretty nice and (normally) smiling when you walk in. I love the big wooden door at the front(don't know why).

Pros: Nice light food with good coffee. Big tables to study on. Free, fast Wifi. Close walk from a number of transit stops. 

Cons: Place can get crowded. Not a lot of plugs for laptops.
author: Chris D.

description: Quiet as a library with the annoying playlist of a college graduate who just discovered The Shins. I like the "one cup at a time" aspect, and the option of choosing your preferred blend. Ample seating and wall outlets are abundant. Don't be surprised if you interrupt someone's conference call at the table next to you.
author: Peter H.

description:
I live in the neighborhood, and lived here years ago, when Samovar used to be a good little coffee shop.  For some reason, I really dislike the Momi Toby's vibe, so I'm stoked to have the Mercury Cafe near by.

I've never been a hang-out-in-coffee-shops-with-lap-top kind of person, but I actually do want to hang out here.  The coffee is great, the art is awesome, the staff is friendly, and I've talked to the owner a few times- what an awesome guy.  When the charity bake sale got rained out, he generously allowed us to move tables around and set up in the cafe for most of the day.  

I need to go more often for sandwiches and beer and stuff.  And I will.
author: Jennifer M.

description: Cool art. Hipster. Mocha and latte. Lots of sunshine. Loud traffic.
author: Yup S.

description: Best damn homemade scones in town! Lunch menu pretty limited but this is the go-to place for brewed by the cup coffee and scones, plus yummy homemade pie.
author: Philip M.

description: I went there to work and have some coffee. The waiter was a bit of a grouch with a holier than thou attitude which rubbed me the wrong way but it didn't ruin the experience. The heavy wood furniture and open windows created a rustic, natural feel that I really liked. I wasn't able to get a table with an outlet for work but I'm sure if I had waited long enough I could have taken a table once it opened up. There is an upstairs table which I would have sat in but it was right next to the office with the office door open and someone working inside so I felt I'd be intrusive. Also the stairway going up to that space was really dirty as was the floor upstairs and the table.  Stay downstairs and enjoy the sun and fresh air.
author: Eliz M.

description: Right now at the top of my fav coffee shop list. Free wi-fi (great for downloading things and watching TV shows when the wi-fi at home goes on the fritz), great coffee and yummy sandwiches. I'm a big fan of the coffee choices which they grind fresh and drip individually. There's a nice selection too. I usually get the El Salvador or Ethopia. And lately I've tried the salami sandwich which comes with a side of greens. It's got really good ground mustard on it too, which is just an extra bonus. It's only $8 too and it always fills me up.
author: Jenna H.

description: This is the slowest internet access I've seen in a while. Don't come here if you have real work to do and need WiFi.
author: Ethan S.

description:
each cup of coffee is individually ground, and brewed upon each order.  now that's some serious coffee if you ask me!  it's nice to have a fresh cup of joe that hasn't been sitting in the pot all day!  great coffee selections as well.

their ice tea is also steeped after ordering.  they have beer, and special happy hour prices.  fresh and delicious homemade desserts, sweet and savory pies, salads, and sandwiches, which are all nicely priced.
author: Sheri N.

description: While visiting a month ago I stumbled upon this corner cafe. The food was tasty and fresh. The service was friendly and helpful. Coffee delightful.
author: Jessica G.

description: Great neighborhood spot that hits all the marks with equally competent breakfast, lunch, coffee and happy hour.  Attractive space with good natural light, friendly staff and consistently delicious food.  Nick pays exquisite attention to detail with his baking and coffee.  The scones are the best I've had in San Francisco.  Raisin walnut are the mainstay with other flavors such as organic strawberry and rhubarb, apple oatmeal, and orange with dark chocolate making seasonal appearances.  And the apple (and other fruit) pies really are that good.  Very large organic, free trade coffee selections and high end espresso equipment make for consistently good drinks.  Lunch options include a very good tuna salad sandwich, and various interesting turkey sandwiches among others.  While others are complaining about the twenty-something hipsters on their iPads, I'm 40 years old and have never once brought a laptop here and always feel welcome and comfortable... and regularly see plenty of folks older than myself as well as a few families with little ones.   WHile service could be a bit slow in the past if baking was taking place, they have recently hired a baker so the wait staff are more freed up.  Really like this place.
author: Michelle L.

description:
I love this place- I really really do.
Their mocha is great- very chocolaty. I also love the sandwiches there! The tuna is YUM! I think the bread they use for the sandwiches is wonderful as well. One negative thing about this place (although I don't want to say it) is that they may be a bit too busy. For the past two times I've come in here, they forgot about my order until I reminded them 20 minutes later.  Of course they were super nice afterwards, and offered me free coffee....but it's still a bit irritating
BUT! This place is still highly recommended. Wonderful for studying.
author: Mika W.

description:
This place is AMAZING. Very cheap and so delicious. They even have a few vegan options! I would go here every day if I lived closer. Absolutely the best coffee place in Hayes Valley and possibly in all of San Francisco.

They have sandwiches and other food, but I didn't try anything besides the vegan blueberry muffins which were to die for. 

Their drip coffee is great. Definitely go here and NOT Blue Bottle Cafe.
author: Amy C.

description: Mercury is one of the best cafés in the city. It feels spacious. There is room to work, our chat. The service is friendly. The coffee is poured by the cup and is perfect. They also offer organic, local food and have a pretty great display of art work. Love it.
author: Wesley C.

description: Great coffee. Free wifi. Ergo lots of laptop users and half-written screenplays. But forget about that and try the scones.
author: Matthew S.

description: OK, they've finally been consistently getting my espresso right; that warrants an extra star.  the owner says that they're close to securing a wine distributor, too -- hooray!
author: Lulu W.

description: We are in need of a good, cheap sandwich place and some to-die-for coffee in these parts. Sidewalk is gone and Momi Toby's coffee isn't what it used to be. I had the Caprese sandwich tonight. Good news, it was $6 and A-Ok. Not fantastic, but good for the money. I'll update once I try their coffee. Fingers crossed!!!
author: Michelle D.

description:
Light and airy space with great staff and AMAZINGLY delicious peanut butter and jelly sandwiches! My wonderfully talented barista gave me a PB&J on the house after I said I was hungry. But I'd go back and pay for one in a heartbeat. Organic peanut butter and fresh jelly from local farms smothered generously over delicious bread. Yum!!  I hope this cafe doesn't go the way of its  predecessor because this place is just what we need in Hayes Valley -- lots of seating, casual/relaxed space, free WiFi and lots of outlets. 

PROS 
Great PB&J sandwiches
Light airy space
Lots of seating, lots of outlets
Free WiFi
Great staff

CONS
Not the best location
Cash only
author: A S.

description: Sorry, Mission Creek...move on over!  This ADORABLE little cafe in Hayes Valley is my new favorite place to study!  The environment is super chill with mellow music: Gorgeous high ceilings with HUGE fish bowl windows.  It almost makes me feel like I'm working outside without the sun glaring on my laptop.  They usually leave the door and windows open which lets a nice breeze in. My gripe with MC was that it was always a little stuffy and the food wasn't all that great. The sandwiches here are awesome and totally affordable!!  Coffee is cheap and totally delicious!  Thanks, Lael, for introducing this place to me.
author: Melissa S.

description: I love, love, love this place. Free wifi. The coffee is great. The food's delish. And, the people are awesome. What more could you ask for?
author: Krista D.

description: I love this place:  Great coffee! Service is delightful! I can sit down and work (wifi too!) plus foods and choice beers on tap! Oh yeah, BIG windows (that open on nice days) so you can see outside.
author: kyle w.

description: Today was the soft opening and as luck would have it, I just had a plate full o' punkin pancakes and salmon croquettes from J's Pots of Soul next door. Serving La Paz coffee, i tested out a doppio and was satisfied. Free wi-fi, an abundance of natural light, walking distance to many a lovely spots (Zen Center, J's Pots of Soul, the queer cultural center, Flax) - I predict many an afternoon foray at this spot. The vibe from the folks was also very welcoming and warm so I imagine a busy neighborhood cafe bustling with locals doing their weekend thang and whiling away the time if J's has a wait.
author: ray e.

description: Tablehopper.com says: Offering coffee from De La Paz - brewed coffee or espresso drinks, plus soup and sandwiches. There will also be homemade pie since owner, Nick Parker, is a pie maker. The opening is another week or so.
author: Colleen B.

description: just discovered Mercury while walking in the neighborhood- cool place; open, airy, art I assume by local artists- very nice, friendly staff; good standard café fare at good prices- I had a bagel with really good hummus, and a cup of tea- good music on, too- will definitely go back. enjoyed sitting at the sidewalk tables.
author: JOHN S.

description: Finally checked this place out to today and it's GREAT!  Low key atmosphere, but with enough character to feel like you're somewhere special.  Love the blue coffee bar, the nice art, the mix of simply white walls and lovely wood floors.  Local comic artist Lloyd Dangle (http://troubletown.com) painted the pole out front, which is a nice touch.  I got some homemade banana bread (which was good), and the staff was super nice.  My apartment is too small for a desk, so I'm really excited to have a good place to work (and not work) so close to home.  Definitely rooting for these guys.
author: Matt W.

description: During my recent trip to San Francisco, I spotted a local coffee shop on the way to Height and Ashbury. The shop has a local charm, and the iced coffee which is brewed in it's rich flavor for 24 hours before serving is especially great. Support the locals..down with Starbucks!
author: Violet S.

description: chillest coffee spot in hayes valley.  awesomely not over the top in a neighborhood that is often a bit much.  solid sandos, sick soy latte, kickass tuneage.  good spot to make laptop work less shoot yourself in the face and more damn i might kind of be a yuppie but the pixies rule.  strong work, mercury.
author: andrew s.

description: OK I went back and tried the coffee again and it was better than I remembered.  I had the Sumatra, which was quite good.
author: Geoffrey U.

description: If there was a sixth star to give, I would do it! Not only did Mercury finally get a return spring on their door, they got TWO! Just to be extra sure and as if to say 'sorry' for all the rainy days some jackass walked out without closing the door behind them.
author: Erika L.

description: checked in here earlier this week to do a little writing...the coffee was absolutely fantastic (i had the ethiopian blend which was recommended by the barista) and the free wi-fi was clutch. such a beautiful, light, and airy space. i hope business picks up here cuz i want this place to stick around!
author: Alicia O.

description: sortof a weird spot, but i got a really good cup of coffee dripped especially for me.
author: Lisa M.

description: Mercury cafe is one of my favorite places to grab a cup of coffee in San Francisco. Working in hayes valley i was getting fed up with waiting in the never ending line at blue bottle only to have someone delivering my coffee with a bit of attitude. Mercury Cafe is the complete opposite! The staff is great and the coffee is even greater! Made in a single cup drip style just as blue bottle but i would say of better quality. And coming from someone who runs my own business I like to know that I'm supporting a local business! Also they always have rotating artwork and great music!
author: amber h.

description: An awesome neighborhood cafe. Good music, delicious food, excellent coffee. Definitely try the house-made chili! The staff is knowledgeable about coffee and incredibly friendly. I will return.
author: Angelina S.

description: Checked out this cafe for the first time and was wowed by the coffee and fresh pastries. We got the homemade apple pie (yummy!) and a few coffees and lattes. Everything was fresh, organic, and delicious. We sat by the open window on a beautiful day and enjoyed the fresh air and music. Overall it was a very relaxing cafe and I'll be sure to return.
author: Leigh S.

description: With the addition of beer and food, this is a pretty safe go-to just about any time.  Great happy hour @ $3, individually made delicious coffees for $1.50, fresh sandwiches using premium ingredients, fresh baked deserts, nice people great space, free wifi, Hayes Valley- are you kidding me?
author: Dave L.

description: what a great addition to the HV...totally light and airy, as others have pointed out, plus the coffee is GOOD--i mean, i love momi toby's like it was home, but for real, the coffee there is often atrocious, and rarely good. plus, this place has super lovely looking organic pastries and when i was in last week, they were just taking an apple pie out of the oven and serving it w/ (optional) cheddar cheese on top, which did my southern heart good. only problem is that w/ the free wifi, how am i supposed to get any real work done? :)
author: Annie M.
